39448450.review:
This is without a doubt one of the most unique gaming experiences I've ever had. See, I'm one of those weirdos that actually liked Black and White, flaws and all. I even liked its sequel. I've been dying for a honest to goodness god sim for years and years and only Dominions 5 has come close. Though I'd more closely compare it to the Disciples franchise. 

Be warned. There's a reason I stopped playing this game. It is very, VERY complex. Each faction in the game features unlimited customization when it comes to your deity. And I do mean UNLIMITED. There's like twenty some odd factions in three different ages. Each of them has their own unique talents that lend better to certain types of builds. The game is ultimately a numbers crunch, calculating the pros and cons of this stat and that magic ability. 

What's most overwhelming to me and most people is the sheer number of options. I like how every faction is a representation of nearly EVERY SINGLE MYTHOLOGY THERE EVER WAS, including the Cthulhu mythos. They even managed to invent a few new ones. That is this game's greatest strength I think. My favorite was leading an army of centaurs and naked women with The Lord of The Wild. 

When it comes to the mathmatical computations needed to fully optimize your playing experience, I'm a dumb dumb. I admit it, I'm not ashamed. This game is not for me. I can appreciate it for both challenging me and filling the void that Black and White left behind. You gotta try it.

39065326.review:
This is an absolutely great game, though it is unlikely to appeal to everyone (do note that you can start the game up outside Steam; I have put many more hours into this game than indicated on Steam).

There are [b]two parts of it that makes it great[/b] in my view: [b]First off, it is a very deep and extremely complex strategy game[/b], with quite a bit of simulation involved, and many different facets and statistics of units and other parts. For instance, age is tracked for every single unit, and this has impact on one's strategy. [b]Second off, it is very rich in its thematic, historical and mythological storytelling, with a focus on simulation, emergent and indirect storytelling[/b]; while there are no campaigns or the like, there are many different nations, spells and creatures, to a very large degree based on real-world nations, mythologies, religion and religious hiearchy, traditions, culture, etc. (there are some nations that are mostly based on fantasy and the like, but it is limited; for instance, there are no orcs or elves here (there are some of the mythologies and creatures from which elves are inspired from, however, like Vanheim with Vanir and Tir na n'Og with Tuatha, Nemedians and Sidhe)). And a lot of the storytelling is given through unit descriptions and unit statistics. And the creators of the game clearly know a lot about ancient real world nations and mythologies, for you can frequently encounter something curious, search on it online, and find that it is a real world part of mythology or history. The Vestal Virgins, for instance, were very important to real-world Rome, and Ermor (read: inspired by early Rome) in the Early Age shows the conflict and change between the old faith and the New Faith, including in which units are available and where, with the Flamen and the Pontifex of the old faith relegated to being recruited in provinces with no major fortifications. Furthermore, the nations change over time in the 3 ages, frequently inspired by or based on how their real-world inspirations changed over time, and this is reflected in the units, spells, abilities etc. that are available as well as in other ways. For instance, T'ien Ch'i (inspired by Ancient China) in the Middle Age is an Imperial Bureaucracy with Celestial Masters, eunuchs, religious ministers and mages of the Way of the Five Elements (and several of their mages are very long-lived based on internal alchemy from Taoism, which can be very helpful), while T'ien Ch'i in the Late Age has been conquered by barbarians and now ruled by them with ancestor worship replacing the mages of the earlier Bureaucracy.

For those that [b]have not played the Dominions series before[/b], I think you may well end up loving this game if [b]extreme complexity is not something that scares you off[/b] (in regards to learning it, there are several different approaches and options, including video tutorials; I liked the Let's Play of an earlier version of the game, found here: https://lparchive.org/Dominions-3/). If you furthermore like learning about real world history and mythology, or like story telling that can be "emergent" and somewhat "simulationist", this is a very nice bonus. [b]If extreme complexity and a steep learning curve can be an issue, I would recommend the series Conquest of Elysium instead[/b] which is also developed by Illwinter. The Conquest of Elysium series shares many traits of the Dominions series but is much lighter on complexity, usually takes much less time and effort to learn and play, and while having some strategic depth is also much more accessible for a wider audience (possibly family-friendly, it is more light-hearted and have a fair bit of humor). Conquest of Elysium also has its own simulationist aspects (different factions need and use different 'biomes' quite differently), and it also has some more RPGish aspects.

For those [b]that have played Dominions 4 and am wondering whether to buy Dominions 5[/b], I would recommend it; there are many smaller and large improvements, the Warriors of the Faith part is only one (though major) aspect: The global map movement system has been changed and revamped fundamentally (for instance, a friendly farmland province with roads and summer-time weather costs 4 map movement points, while mountains in cold scales may cost 18 map movement points. Heavy infantry typically has lower map movement points than light infantry), and there are multi-turn movement planning available (you may have to turn it on in the options; also note it was a bit flaky in my experience, though worked fairly well overall); Battles are executed real-time; In addition to Income and Resources, every province has Recruitment points, and units take up different amounts of recruitment points; Commanders likewise take up Commander points, which can be increased by higher-level fortifications (this means that you can potentially recruit multiple scouts in one province in one turn); It is no longer possible to build add-ons to fortifications, instead you always start by building palisades or similar, and instead can upgrade that fortification to the next level available to you (like 'Palisades -> Castle -> Citadal'); A bunch of very nice UI upgrades and short-cuts (remember to use '?' to see the short-cuts available for the current GUI window); Improved random map generation; Snow/cold scale affects movement and snow is shown on the global map; Retreatment is handled differently and smarter units and commanders has a higher chance of making it to friendly territory; The borders between your dominion and others' dominion can be turned on to be highlighted; Storming castles now features actual missile troops standing on the walls instead of missiles being fired from towers; And a bunch of other nice things. Overall, my experience with the changes and improvements and the newest version of the game as a whole have been good. That said, [b]I have not yet played this game in multiplayer[/b]; for whether the changes are good or bad in that regard, please see the reviews of others.

38865066.review:
I have to admit when I first loaded this game up, my instinct was to promptly refund it. I saw the crappy graphics and saw that battles automated and thought to myself, "Yuck!" However, some of the fans on the forums told me I had to give it a shot and play at least one game through. Well, I am a sucker for proving games suck when they suck, so I did.

I am glad I did. This game is seriously deep and strategic. I haven't played any game where the player has so many decisions to make in quite a while. I found myself planning things like, "Ok, if I try to get some forests, crank out some mages there, rush my research for alteration, then buff my bowmen in battle, while protecting them with these shield guys..." or "Maybe I can use a pretender with air, so I can crank out quills and get my research faster in order to raise the dead, because there will be mounds of corpses." I mean, I laid in bed at night with thoughts like those dancing through my head. That to me, is a successful game.

The game is a province grabber. 

You start the game with a powerful pretender, which is someone or some creature, fighting others for godhood. You acheive godhood by taking over the map or taking key provinces with thrones on them. You can spend an hour or two just going through the options to pick your nation, pretender, and his dominion (bonuses or penaltied to the are you control basically). I don't mean, giving him a cool haircut either, I mean options that effect the core of your strategy and make game changing differences..

You then start out with a main province, start cranking out troops made up of varioius units available to your nation. Here is where the game really sets itself apart. Every nation in the game has unique troops, some unquie spells, and a vastly unique way of playing. Think about the first time you "learned the zerg" vs "learned the protoss" and then multiply that by 20.

After you crank out your troops, you and your pretender, if you chose to start with him awake rather than asleep for extra points, go out and conquer surrounding provinces. As you conquer, each province contains various independant troops that may do better or worse against certain troop compositions and battle setups. Once conquered, you get income, resources, and you may also recruit from those provinces for troops that didn't come with your nation. Perhaps you will run across a province that gives you sages so you can research faster, or druids who open up nature magic, or mermen so you can invade the sea! So many options!

The battles themselves are automated. I usually hate automated battles. But you do have a good amount of control. Way way more than most games with scripted battles. You can setup the positions of your squads, set thier formations, take along various commanders, and the initial spells your commanders will be using, and tell each squad or commander to attack a particular type, like attack calvary, for example. You can also make them wait and attack, retreat, hold for a bit and then attack, etc. How you set up your battles really does make a difference and you will spend some hours toying with the different options in order to devide the most effective killing machine in terms of losses and speed of expansion.

As you take land, you can build forts, temples, and laboratories on them. The former allowing for more effective collection of resopurces and defenses in the province. The temples spread your dominion (worship of your pretender) and allow for recruitment of priests, and the latter allow for recruitment of your mages and use of magic spells, rituals, and the like. Yet, more strategy! Where will I spend my preciouis little gold to create a stronghold to defend my lands? Do I need to spread my dominion of death clouds killing of my enemies without even having to send troops? Perhaps I want to build a lab, so I can teleport my key unit from way across the map for a sneak attack.

The game is just chalk full of decisions to be made. I've always said, with strategy titles, the more decisions that I have to make, the better.

So, if you are like me, and are think you might be interested, but are put off by the indie look, give it a shot. It might become one of your favorite games!

38767367.review:
[h1]珠玉のターン制ファンタジー陣取り合戦シミュレーター[/h1]

このシリーズに出会って受けた「最初の衝撃」については前作のレビューに書いたので、まずはそちらを参照して頂くとして…

http://steamcommunity.com/id/sakalab/recommended/259060/

今回はもう少し冷静に違った視点で書いてみようと思います。

例えば、ゲーム開発会社の規模を大、中、小、個人の4分類とすると、一回の失敗で頓挫しやすいのは社員になまじ給料を払わなければならない中小のデベロッパーでしょう。過去の例を見ても、中小から可能性のあるゲームの芽が出ても発展途中で終わってしまう事が非常に多いように感じます。逆に個人開発の場合、結果がすぐに出なくてもしぶとく生き残れる可能性があります。そして長い年月をかけて一つのゲームのブラッシュアップが繰り返され、時として「バケモノ級に成熟したゲーム」が生まれることがあります。このDominionsシリーズがその典型的な例の一つです。

このゲームが最初にリリースされたのは2002年。初期のv1.00から15年の歳月をかけて延々とブラッシュアップが繰り返され、現在の最新バージョンがv5.09。これがつまりDominions5の5の意味するところです。このシリーズでは、メジャーバージョンが上がる際に過去バージョンからその主要なエッセンスを継続する事に細心の注意が払われており、一般のように新作が出る度に別のゲームになっていないか？といった心配をする必要はまずありません。この長期間に渡る洗練、成熟がこのゲームに深みを与えており、他の類似ゲームが真似のできない奥深さの根源となっているのだと思います。

[h1]自分がこのゲームに感じているユニークな部分を以下に列挙[/h1]

■緻密な戦闘シミュレーション
独自の乱数をはじめとして、攻撃属性、命中部位、迎撃、疲労など、見た目からは想像も及ばないような緻密な戦闘システム、計算式が裏で動いている。 

■膨大なデータ量
ビジュアルを最小限に抑える事で唯一無二のデータ量を実現。選択肢は膨大となり、かつカウンター的な要素も多い為、ストラテジーゲームにおいてプレイヤーが最も楽しい時期である「定石探索フェーズ」が延々と続く。

■驚異的なリプレイ性
戦略の根幹となる神（国家主導者）設計のカスタマイズの幅が広い。これと各種のデータ量が組み合わされれば、リプレイ性は最早無限。「研究対象物」としても興味深く、解析、設計、実験に耐える奥深さはマニアのツボを刺激する。

■PBEMマルチとの抜群の相性
PBEM（Play By EMail）とは、参加者が同じ日時に集まらなくてもできる非同期マルチプレイの事。自由時間の確保が難しい社会人でも空き時間でマルチプレイが楽しめる。DominionsのシステムはこのPBEMとの相性が抜群であり、日本のコミュニティーでもマルチが開催されている。日本でこういった楽しみ方ができるストラテジーゲームは滅多に存在しない。

■開発の継続性
今後数年に渡るメンテナンスと新要素追加が保証されている。途中で開発が居なくなる心配が無い。コアユーザーからのフィードバックも多く、バグの撲滅、バランス調整は最高レベルが期待できる。DLC商法も無い。（初期投資4千円程度はむしろ安いとさえ言える）

■ロアー的な楽しみ
国家やユニット、アイテムなどは実在した古代文明、王朝、神話、民話、伝承などをモデルにしたものが多く、名前をGoogle検索するだけで世界が何倍にも膨らむ。フレーバーテキストからもそういった背景を垣間見られる。

■独自のファンタジー世界
ファンタジーを題材としている為、ドラゴンやアンデッド、魔法など、おなじみの要素が楽しめる。一方で、エルフやドワーフは指輪物語以前の伝承からの採用の為、扱いが一般とは異なる。

■日本語Wikiの充実
過去シリーズから、本国を凌ぐほど充実した凄まじい日本語Wikiが提供されている。既に最新作のDominions5版サイトも立ち上がり着々と作成が進んでいる。

■充実したサポート
日本にもゲームを愛するコアユーザーが存在し、Discord上でレスポンスの良い質問部屋が運営されている。困ったらチャットで聞いて即解決という充実したサポートを受けられる。（ゲーム自体の敷居が高い為、特に初心者には積極的な利用を推奨）


[h1]購入前の注意点[/h1]

■ビジュアルに期待しない
ユニットの描写や演出などはシミュレーターとして最低限の違いを判別できれば良い程度に抽象化されている。見た目に期待する人は購入すべきではない。

■ユーザーインターフェイスに慣れが必要
5で少し改善したとはいえ、UIはわかり易いとは言い難い。慣れれば何の問題もないが、最初はしばらく我慢が必要。

■チュートリアル不足
5では4で存在していたチュートリアルも無くなった（動画説明へ切り替え）。初心者は4版の日本語Wikiなどを参照しつつ基本を学ぶ必要あり。システムはそれほど変わっていないので、4のTipsなどはそのまま使える内容が多い。

■5の日本語化について
アイテム・スペル・ユニットの日本語化が有志にて進行中。システムメッセージなどは現時点で日本語化の目途は立っていない。ストーリーを重視するゲームでは無いので、長文読解が必要な場面は殆どない。英語が苦手でもプレイは可能。


[h1]リンク[/h1]

Steam日本語コミュニティー　Discord部屋への招待、マルチ開催、等
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/DomJP

5版日本語Wiki　Dom4から5での変更点まとめ
https://dom5wiki.gamelore.fun/?List%20of%20Improvements

4版日本語Wiki　初心者向けTips
http://wikiwiki.jp/dominions4/?Beginner%20Information

38522896.review:
Very good game, just nested behind a strange (but useful) UI. I bought the last one for 4 bucks and got mad at how ugly it was. Came back the next day and played for 4 hours straight. 

The game's a good time, but it's not for the faint of heart. It's straightforward but deep. You build a pretender (sorta your race's super unit) and then you set up what sort of effect the pretender has on the world, then you pick your race and you go. 

You recruit dudes, then assign them to commanders, then order the commanders to move onto other territories. If there's a commander there you fight them.

The complexity of the game comes into the squad positioning and composition because you can't actually control the battles; they're done in-between turns and you're watching the replay later. You can research spells to summon in blood waves or spies, you can seduce other commanders, you can slit their throats, you can teleport across the map.

The UI ends up being nearly perfect in a lot of ways; a ton of stuff to do and a bunch of keys to press to do it. The game's visual simplicity allows for you to accept the things the game tells you is happening. "Oh sure, of course there's demon's gate opening up", even though its basically a red icon on the map and a bunch of demons.

tl;dr its a fun niche game, you need to get over the first hour or two of not understanding anything and then maybe watching some tutorials. I've got 20 hours in this one, and I hope to play 20 more.

This is a deep 4x strategy game that suffers from a lack of graphics support. Its crippled from a lack of player friendly tutorials, no in game tooltips, and has an archaic and unwieldy User Interface. It does have hundred + page PDF manual that is generally unhelpful. Older versions of this manual used to include a tutorial, but the game designers decided to remove it in Dominions 5.

Its a game created and run by two people as a hobby, and this is apparent in the lack of attention to detail with interface and graphics elements. It is so newbie unfreindly that I would not recommend this to anyone.

Also, it lacks a modern multiplayer form of play that one would expect from a game with this price tag. Its best form of multiplayer is play be email. Something right out of the 1980s and 90s.

Last, but certainly not least, the user community is hostile and generally conceited. 

UPDATE: After over a month since the game released, several game breaking bugs have been widely identified and reported on by the community at large. Specifically:

1. Attack Rear breaks flank attack mechanic.
2. The new simultaneous battles break archery, targeting, flanking maneuvers, and in some cases evocation spell targeting for AoE spells.
3. Auto scripting now appears to randomly spam counter-intuitive spells for no reason such as Blink, and Communion Slave when no communion has been started.
4. Repel changes to the game further broke cavelry charge effectiveness.
5. Units with Trample ability disregard Awe, Vine Shield effects, and many other things.
6. New bless mechanics when combined with sacred flyers and cavelry units create game breaking effects. 
7 The Map Editor has been reported to crash the game.

There are now over a dozen bug report multi-page threads clearly explaining all of these bugs. The lead developer, Kristoffr, admitted in several of them that he though the new Simultaneous Battle system had unintended consequences.

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME until it has been fixed, Game companies need to learn to stop releasing poorly tested games that they rush to release to cash in a few more $$$.

This review is mainly targeted at new players; I am new to Dominions myself and haven't played any of the prequels, so I can't speak to the comparison to any past version.

Do not be daunted by the immendiate complexity of this game--If you take a bit of time to listen/watch the introduction videos that are posted on the game's site, or even just reading through the manual provided in game, you will be rewarded with a 4x experience that rivals even the best. I'm a huge fan of these kinds of games, and this one really hit the spot.

Pros:
A TON of nations to choose from. The different ages change the mechanics of the nations in them, and the general tone of the world. The general scale is the later the age, the less powerful the mage.

Each nation has a ton of god options. This can be daunting to choose, but the game nudges you towards certain choices by reducing the point cost of that god for the nation you're in.

Each nation plays fundementally differently. You can't play Xibalba like Pangaea, or you'll end up with a lot of dead bats. Some nations need different scales to thrive. Some nations need you to change up your playstyle or use of special units. 

The random maps are gorgeous and well balanced.

Cons:
This game is obviously building on a library of knowledge set up by the 4 previous, and therefore can be daunting to get into for a new player.

Multiplayer is a pain to set up.

Games can go long, so you've got to be willing to commit.

The game doesn't do a great job of communicating what you need to be doing. If you're new to the 4x genre, this game isn't for you.

Tl;dr This game is an amazing pick up if you're a 4x fan and willing to put in the effort to learn the mechanics. It's not an easy start, but it's extremely rewarding, fun, and challenging.

If you were to take Magic the Gathering, with all of it's card options, synergies, and complexities, and then remove the card aspect, then turn that into a war strategy game, Dominions would be it.

There's just so much you can do with your nation, your god, your spells, your troops, how your troops engage in combat, that you can keep playing this for years and still think up new strategies that are wildy different than your previous playthroughs. Add in random map generation, and also the option to download converted custom maps that others have made, it makes this game have huge replay value.

Want to stampede the enemy with a mob of fiery knights? Play MA Marignon. Want to send huge waves of undead hordes across the world? Play as MA Ermor. But how you do that is up to you. You can fine tune and tweak to your hearts content. A huge variety of spells to use, troop types, item creation (ie, giving your commanders fiery swords, black plate armor, etc), creature summons, the list goes on.

That's why I compare it to Magic the Gathering, tons of options, lots to do, and a lot of synergies for you to figure out. It's fun to try out new things and see what works, what doesn't, and what could work if tweaked a bit.

The only drawback to the game for some, would be it's graphics. It's not the best, looks pretty dated. But, the game has tons to do, and it's dripping with interesting lore.

The game is fun in single player, and also fun in multiplayer, depending on your cup of tea. Although, if you want some form of diplomacy, you'd want to play multiplayer, then you can contact others and form alliances and such. Single player doesn't have diplomacy, but ultimately, it wouldn't make much since if it did. Your ultimate goal is to become GOD, and you don't share power.

38262888.review:
I have played many 4X strategy games, and this is my first Steam review. 

- Why am I giving this a review?

Because the Dominions series has been a breath of fresh air to my number-crunching, grand-strategising self, capturing a niche in the market which other games just don't fill: 

(TL:DR - summary of other titles here, skip to below if desired)

*Speaking from a single player perspective*: AoW is nice, but becomes a 'Tier-4 Spamfest' with rampantly-scaling economies which sadly grows dull (and leads to unfinished games). Civ gets boring after a while, especially the routine tactics dealing with spam-fest nature of AI bonuses on diety levels (I like a challenge to be a challenge, not a grind). Fallen Enchantress is more of the same with dull endless hordes and cheese tactics late-game (little challenge). TW games tend to be broken down into economy, doom-stacks, horribly fast battlefield sludgefests and dodgy movements/abuse of AI. Endless Legend is a nice touch and with reasonable late-game scaling, but still becomes predictable. Warlock could have been a great game, but the AI was useless, the game abandoned, and the MP scene with it. Warband was cool, but becomes repetitive after a while (looking forward to the next though). 
Do I know what I am talking about? I would hope so, after over 1000 hours racked up on such games (including MP).

(TL:DR over)

So why do I love the Dominion series? Surely it can get predictable, abusable and dull just like the rest? *Note: I have recently discovered it, and am only on about 40 hours playtime so far*

- Firstly: replayability. So many nations and so much diversity, troop types, magic paths, ways to influence both game and battlefield. 

- Secondly: RPG and character investment: the choice of characters, magic items, possible abilities, etc., is huge. And yes, your beloved mage with great equipment and boosted magic paths *will* die horribly in the end....maybe...probably.

- Thirdly: surprises and strategies. Even the AI, using more basic AI strategy, will catch you off guard with new unit types, spells, mage-heavy armies, flyers and cavalry taking out your back lines, large armies or elite squads you didn't see coming, and attacks on your weak flanks.

- Fourthly: pace. If you are a serious and patient strategist, you will get great pleasure out of the development of your empire and borders. The diversity of potential magic sites, Thrones, bonuses, and special units you can attain is great, and the strategic vs min/max layer of fort placement and province defense is also great

- Fifth: customisation. Setting up a game with 'story events' turned on and finding your capital assailed by demon horsemen who you are not ready to take out is.... amusing. Customisation of victory conditions and team games is fine, and it all adds to varying experiences and challenges

- Sixth: learning curve progression. I have not even ventured into Multiplayer yet, still learning to 'get gud' in SP - but I am aware MP is where the real skill and strategy lies. By about the point where the game could get dry and I can actively use strategies which dominate any AI, congratulations to me... I am ready to get stomped in MP by strategies based on pre-planned empire/magic/troop designs and advanced reactions to the strategies/army-comp/item-use I am implementing. 

- Seventh: no other game combines all these elements and options for me

- Eighth: the game seems to do a reasonable job of balancing and scaling. Sure, the way to pull ahead is to have more provinces, meaning stronger economy and more troops....but you have to know how to use it, and multiple opponents can still pull you down. Economy scaling is not a thing like it is in other titles, where the percentages get silly.

- Ninth: when you learn cool tactics, spells, blesses, designs and strategies which walk all over the AI, SP is not over! you can simply challenge yourself by not setting up a nation in this way, with those bless designs or magic paths. Restrictions (i.e. not resorting to overwhelming strategies the AI can't cope with) do not need to feel like restrictions *as in other titles* - simply design choice and a new challenge, a new race to learn and a new way to play them


Negatives or alternate arguments:

- is the game worth the price, and is it enough of an improvement on Dom4? To me, yes. It adds enough, and brings new possibilities. As someone who enjoys the titles, I am happy paying up knowing the game should continue to improve. If there are expansions, I will also buy those. 
- What about if you are strapped for cash? You can get enough of a Dominions experience from Dom4, so if you already have it... you could wait for sale if you don't like the price. 
- If, however, you don't own Dom4... get this.
- If you *really* like Dom4... get this. It is an improvement
- If you don't have as much patience as you thought you did, or need quick-fix strategy games... maybe watch YouTube videos first. 
- If you don't want a game with a steep learning curve, where *only* many hours invested will give you any sense of how to play the game.... turn away. Run. You are not the market this game is reaching out to.

In other negative news, my super-mages died. Horribly. Disease is a thing, as are arrows, centaurs, assassins, drownings, elemental effects, and cyclopses.

This lengthy report comes to you from a very good 4X player (max difficulty other titles), an intermediate Dom5 noob, and Dom5 multiplayer virgin soon to be crushed by ethereal bless effects, supercombatants, and stealthy raids on all my provinces. I might even enjoy it.

38243893.review:
Simply the best 4x strategy available on the market. There's so much depth and detail to everything in this game, yet it can still be enjoyed casually. So many welcome improvements over 4, from being able to queue multiple move commands for one commander in one turn, real time combat which is fun to watch, the new bless effect system, and more.

If you're new to the series, this isn't your typical 4x strategy title. For example, most of your province improvements will come from random events, which, depending on how you've set up your pretender god (basically your main hero unit)  in the beginning can heavily influence what occurs. If you have a high luck stat, say, 3 luck, then you'll have 15% more events per turn, and 30% higher chance the event is good. However, provinces themselves can also modify their individual attributes through random events, and some provinces may flip in fortune. (and of course you won't be impervious to bad events.) Your manual improvements are limited to building a palisades/wall which upgrades into a castle, (gives you advantageous positioning and ability to defend the tile better versus enemy attacks, as well as store supplies so more units can be on that tile and not starve.) a laboratory(which can be used to transfer magical items, and research magic on that tile, as well as access your magic stones to cast ritual spells/transfer them for combat) and a temple. (which spread your gods dominion, which if you lose all dominion/faith in your god, it will disappear, and you will immediately lose the game.)    Most of the focus will be on building your army, strategically placing your defenses, and planning your offense, as well as spreading your dominion with your priests, and temples, and utilizing your resources to cast ritual spells/research higher tiers of magic for your fights.

The combat in this game has got to be my absolute favorite of any similar game, [url=http://www.illwinter.com/dom5/dom5manual.pdf]Dominion Random Number (Page 11)[/url]. To simplify it, When you roll for a random number, you'll roll either one(rarely) or two six-sided die, if either result is 6, then you subtract 1, and roll that die again. (that is, a 5 added to the roll, and each time you keep rolling a 6, you keep going until you no longer roll 6, add up the result and that's the result.)  What this means, is although improbable, nothing is truly impossible. You could see a bizarre scenario such as a single militia unit take down a dragon, however in all likeliness in over thousands of hours, you may see this once, or never. Quality is not quantity, you're still relying on individual unit strengths, and their abilities and utilizing them for their purposes. 

An example (straight from the manual): It means that if you have a Jotun Moose Rider with attack skill 9 and your
opponent has an Abysian Infantry with defense skill 10, your chance of beating him with two openended
dice (and thus scoring a hit) is 38%. If the values were reversed, your chance of success would be
54%.
The reason for the disjunction is that, at the zero point, you must roll higher (due to if the opponent rolls the same, then they've still protected themselves from the damage, thus meaning at the zero point, you have a 46% chance to beat your opponent.)

The units, spells, items, and events in this game are very in depth... You can generally take them at face value, literal descriptions, and expect things stated in them to occur. In the case of events, something may occur that just sounds like flavor text, but there's actually a chance that an event will occur later based on the one that just occurred and continue that string of events along causing perhaps ettins to assault your province later on. Different kinds of weapons hit different kinds of armor differently, and armor isn't just flat protection, it only protects [b]that[/b] part of the body which it is equipped on, you can receive crippling injuries, afflictions which affect you permanently such as losing an eye, an arm, and so forth... Each individual unit can gain experience and sometimes due to their injuries may die while trekking to a new location. This game is pretty much the perfect mix of dungeons & dragons level complexity into a 4x strategy title. 

For actual battles, you can script out the starting sequences that your troops will them attempt to follow for each battle they're pit against, (you don't control any units in the actual combat, think Total War.... with far more depth) while not necessary in the beginning stages, you may need to do this in order to seize victory against higher quality troops and quantity of attacks later on, optimizing your buffs, gem usages, and positioning. Each troop, being an individual as before, has a morality check, if something demoralizing happens, such as being wounded, having someone die, or magical effects (fear, for example), if they fail the morality check, then they may begin to rout, if too many members of the squad have been demoralized, then the entire squad will have a rout check, if that passes the entire squad will rout and disperse into neighboring friendly territory (if possible). Furthermore, if your commanders are all vanquished, then the squads will rout.   Proper battle planning and getting the most out of your resources and troops can carry you a long way.   However... Too much focus on batte can lead to your downfall as well.

You're fighting for the throne, The supreme ruler has suddenly disappeared, and the world is in turmoil, prayers aren't being granted, and that's where you step in. You're a Pretender God, and the creation for said god is incredibly in depth, and will shape your nation, from the effects of provinces in your dominion, to the actual stats and when the physical form of your god actually awakens. It's important to realize that without faith, your god can't exist. If all of your dominion is gone (the faith in your god, and your provinces can worship false idols/other pretender gods), then you immediately lose the game. Equally important to the battles is spreading your dominion, the name of your god, and his/her/it's deeds far and wide, as well as claiming the Thrones of Ascension. In order to do so, your god or prophet must be on that tile to claim it . Thrones will often be heavily guarded by either a large number of units, or a small number of very powerful units capable of wiping entire armies out by themselves... often a single unit with incredible power. By claiming a throne, its abilities can aid you, and/or cause a global enchantment to occur. 

The ways of victory are either to: Claim all the thrones of ascension, Spread your dominion so that every province worships your god, wipe out every other god, or... Have the most thrones claimed when the cataclysm ends. If there are any thrones left, (in that event, the horrors called by the cataclysm will win the game.)

All of this, and I haven't really gotten into any of the deeper details, as others have pointed out, there's an insurmountable amount of content and depth this game has to offer... Mercenaries for example, can be hired on any tile you own in your province, providing you're the highest bidder of said mercenary during that month. They'll be in your service for 3 months after, before returning to being able to be purchased to the highest bidder, and like everything else in the game... The mercenaries have depth as well, Each mercenary unit is an actual unit, that can lose members of its squad, and need to recruit more, accrue permanent afflictions, and even die. If a mercenary unit is wiped out, it can't be bought. I've run out of space to write, so I'll leave you with this: This is a must play title if you like strategy games. The soundtrack is awesome as well, and I implore you to give it a chance. There's so much depth that I can't go into detail here because of the word count, and others probably explain it better anyways. Check it out, You won't regret it.

Every iteration of dominions has added subtle but significant improvements, and dominions 5 is no exception.

The changes to the battle system make it so that it's significantly harder to get cheesy tactics to work.  This also has the side effect of making the AI a little more competitive.  A single shielded infantry won't draw all arrow fire, and units guarding commanders can't manipulate control of the battle as easily.  Cavalry units seem pretty useful again.  The map movement changes are a little confusing to understand at times, but seems like it will make raiding more fun and effective, and no longer restricted to flying units.  I also think the changes to commander recruitment makes a lot of sense;  it's no longer quite as clear that forts should do nothing but infinitely produce mages.  The new blessing setup opens up a whole host of new strategic options.  Couple that with all the nations and units available, there's a ridiculous amount of replayability in this game.


No other fantasy 4x comes close to touching this game, especially for multiplayer.  I will concede that the in-game multiplayer support is comparatively minimal.  However, the PBEM server solves this issue thanks to the tremendous effort of llamabeast. I also want to recognize Lars for the wonderful work on the mod inspector utility.

This is somehow deep and quite interesting game. Though version 5 is more or less the same as version 4. 

I would point few weaknesses anyway.

- Novice unfriendly

Looks like getting started without manual or some extended reasearch is an issue. You need to find out what spells are critically important and where to get them. The same for crafted items, what is even more an issue because they are not as visible as spells. Though you may need to try many spells (especially summons) to get idea why you would need one. There is also very important "n" shortcut for which there is no GUI button.

Overall the combination of nations. eras, spells, items etc etc makes it very problematic to play with some good understanding what's going on. Earth elementals attacking your mages? Why? Abominations or other unknown beasts devastating your entire armies? What to do? And so on. You need not just have basic understanding of your own nation and available tools, but also understanding of every other nation in contact. And this is really tough, as there are many very different nations.

And what's that? There are games with steep learning curves. Right. But I feel that here we have much complexety in favor of more complexety rather than gameplay, while some key points are hidden rather than explained. For novice player it ever looks like chess where every other player has its own set of figures and you don't know how they move yet! In fact novice player doesn't even know many of his own (especially spells and items).

- Micromanagement issues

Each turn selecting what your mages should cast or forge? Want to know how many of your units are desised or wounded to consider some healing? Click every 100 of them and count. Well, with so many things going on good luck to manage everything here and avoid being feebleminded. Even of smallest map!

And who ever invented the rule that units should retreat to all 6 different provinces?

- Uninspiring battles

The more I play this game the more I don't like how battles are going. Is there ever a way to make it interesting when you can't imagine what a spell your mages will cast? What to say if you don't always know with whom you will battle, or will you ever still be alive before battle begins.

I know we can choose some spells for start. But this is not a solution. You still can't control how they are cast. Not saying that against different enemies different spells needs to be chosen, but you could not know everytime what enemy it will be. You can't be ready for everything and that creates too much chaos to be enjoyable.

===

This game cries for serious redesign. Being old-school is not enough this day. So much could be improved here.

Also I don't remember so long battle calculation (up to an hour?) in Dominions 4.

38048652.review:
I have been playing the series for close to 15 years now, and it only keeps getting better.

Dominions is pretty much the Dwarf Fortress of 4x games. It is an extremely nuanced and detailed simulation that will require literal years to just sample what it has to offer, much less master it all. On the other hand, just as with Dwarf Fortress you can easily play it on a rather casual level if that is your preference. Unlike Dwarf Fortress, it is a game that shines in multiplayer, though single-player games are absolutely possible.

Most of the turn-based gameplay takes place either on the overhead strategic map, or studying (if not just enjoying) the animated battle replays. While the player has no direct control over troops during combat (something that actually adds to the gameplay in my opinion), the troops will attempt to follow pre-set orders issued prior to the engagement. This is an extremely crucial part of Dominions as a series, as building appropriate battle scripts can easily take longer than any other part of the game. For a lot of the fights this will not be necessary, and you can simply rely on basic orders, but taking on more dangerous armies will greatly benefit from customized orders.

There is an entire elaborate magic system in place (both to research, utilize during combat or for strategic benefits, and use for artifact creation), as well as a fully customizable character equipment system for your commanders. While you cannot equip general troops separately, there is a large collection of spells modifying things with individual to army-wide effects.

Frankly, the game is so complex that it would take days simply to describe all the potential it carries. The amount of customization assures that for a long time each game can be played completely different way.

$40 might seem like a lot, but the amount of content included easily matches games like Crusader Kings 2 or Europa Universalis IV with all the DLC Paradox sold separately, which really does make it a bargain. On top of that, you are getting Illwinter's outstanding post-release support (Dominions 4, a game released in 2013, still received a major update a few months back).

If you enjoy grand strategy games and never tried the Dominions series, you are missing out on one, if not the, best titles ever released, and certainly the most detailed one.

Dominions 5: Among the dozens of Imperial Generals, Commander Bas Tardo was young, cocky, and green as grass. 

He started his campaign (that eventually carried his force across the empire, over the Silver Mountains to the dark lands beyond) with a legion of imperial cavalry and foot. Step by bloody step, Bas Tardo's Brigade carved a bloody swathe across the land in the name of their living god.

After each of his countless battles, he replenished his losses with foreign infantry, barbarian outriders, ogres, hill giants, deserter janissaries, conquered beastmen, crystal wizrds, witch doctors, undead thralls, griffons, fire lizards, and mercenaries of all kinds. He lost an eye and gained a limp. He contracted jungle rot and battle tremors; he went slightly mad; and in the end, after fording the Black River for a strike into a kingdom of heathens, he was afflicted by a wasting plague that would lay him low. 

His army fought a series of desperate pitched battles near the enemy capital, culminating in a siege of the foreign king's fortess. After his loyal captains carried him forth (he had grown too weak to walk in his black plate armor) and seated him on his dread charger Skelgrenn, he led the charge that broke the enemy lines and won the day--and cemented his name in the annals of imperial military legend. 

That night, Lord Bas Tardo died peacefully in his slumber, attended by a couple of camp hookers. RIP.

10/10

38035874.review:
I bought Dom 5 just yesterday and started 2 games, 1 random map game and 1 game on the cradle map, which is still one of the best maps in the game( you can download it from the map subforum).

I consider myself a veteran dominions player, having played  a lot of single player and multiplayer in Dom 2 and Dom 3 very succesfully.
Dom4 I never played in MP but I did play some really long lasting SP games  on the glory of gods map using Mods to strengthen the AI at the highest difficulty setting.

I think dom5 is definitely worth the money, it feels much better polished than Dom4 and also better balanced ...which is a pretty big achievement from the devs considering this game is only out for some days now.
As usal, the devs will do a lot patches for years and you can expect a ton of mods from the community to further increase playing experience as well as quite a bunch of new and  beautiful maps.

Here is my pros and cons compared to Dom4 :

Pros:

General and pre game :

- The Music is great, usually i turn off the music right from the start in most games I did play over the years, but not  in Dom5

- The game is much better optimzed for higher resolutions so that I dont get pain in the eye playing it , like I did in Dom3 and Dom4 playing on widescreen.

- Random maps get much better results and are generated really fast even when doing huge maps

- starting choices are much better, pretenders are pretty good balanced even without mods and the scales you can choose are also slightly tweaked to make all choices pretty good and viable.

- I really like that you can now choose what bless effects you want for sacred units, also some nations get bonis for some blesses. This isnt very well balanced at this point though( look at cons later on)

- The screens are much more polished and its much easier to get important informations already at pretender design, e.g. about unit roster of the nation

- You get more options for the game: Hall of Fame can now consist of up to 20 names, global enchantments can be upped to 9 at once,etc.

I would recommend to set resources at least to 200% and supplies to the maximum (300%) if you want to play vs better AI. This results in the AI recruiting more and better troops in its forts.It does make the game also slightly easier for you but the good thing is: There are also recruitment and commander points that do limit unit availability on top of money/rescources/holy points.

In game:

- There are many more things visible on the global map, most changes are good some are not( look at cons, especially I have a hard time seeing temples now)

- Commander and recruiting points are really nice. Most mages cost 2-4 points and starting region usally has 3 commander points, you can churn out 1 high level mage every 1,5 tunrs...or choose to make 3 assassins at once

- Forts start at lowest level and can be upgraded which gives additional commander points, more income and there seems to be a special fort defense now on top of province defense, which also gets better with upgrading.

- Research is much less complicated and less micro management, while still being equally deep and requiring planning , great change

- AI seems to be better in vanilla dom 5 compared to vanilla dom 4. Most armies I did encounter so far ,consisted of more national troops

- Battles are played out a lot faster, since attacker and defender hit at once and not after one another.
This makes battles a lot less real life time comsuming to watch , which to me was one of the biggest drawbacks in all old dom games. Since I like huge maps and usually play at hardest difficulty possible and mods that make it even harder, it took a ton of time to watch battles in all my SP and MP games. This time is roughly cut in half i would say.

- Battles seem to be more bloody because of this change, too. This did result in some balance problems though( see cons). But overall I do like it, since even a good player will lose more units per battle, which in turn makes the AI slightly harder to beat. No more finetuning starting position of units/commanders pre battle in order to get the first hit.Good change.

- multi turn movement for commanders can be activated pre game. A simple but great change. You dont have to "babysit" all your commanders now, since they automatically follow the movement path to destination every turn.

- The fatigue system has been slightly reworked. I still hate this system in general but it has less impact now on the game, making units with high armor(and thus high fatigue) a bit  better now. They still are handicapped because of slow movement though and it is my impression that movement in battles now is more important than before.

- + many more changes that are good

Cons:

- game only comes with 2 or 3 premade maps. Sure , random maps are much better now but still...this isnt enough.
Where are all the classic dom 2-4 maps that came with vanilla release?
Sure, the community is very active and therefore we will have enough maps very soon...but not every player of Dom 5 will visit the forum/dom sites to download them.

- Blessing choices are great but not very well balanced at this point. Also there seem to be some bugs:
 
Undying also seems to work for non undead sacreds and only costs 1 bless point...this is extremely powerful since you can take it several times at pretender generation.
You only need 4 bless points to get to +3 magic resistance...this is also extremely powerful.

All in all this is still a great change, at least once patches and mods are out.

- the new global map has its drawbacks:
 1. I have a hard time seeing temples
 2. I loved the candles displaying the dominion strength, they seem to have disappeared, instead you get your provinces highlighted in yellow that have your dominion. So far so good, but you have now to click on the province to see the actual dominions strength AND on some maps that use a green/yellow color pattern for most provinces,e.g. cradle,  you simply cant see the yellow highlighted province very easy.
 3. Cold provinces will be colored differently and behave differently...looks good on paper, but this vastly improves all nations liking cold climate and vastly hampers hot climate nations imo. I
 This is a pretty big balance issue I have right atm.

- while battles result in more casualties now, which is good, assassins are right now a ton weaker.
I played LA Abysia in my test games and loved to conquer neutral provinces with Assassins, killing the commanders and then just sending one commander of my own to conquer the province.
This Strategy was balanced before imo, since I had to invest quite some time and money in order to make that strat work...and here and there my assassins would be killed,too. Since both combatants hit and once now, most assassins either die alone or manage to die but poison the enemy commander so that he dies ,too. Very rarely Ive seen my blessed assassins to kill neutral province commanders and survive. This makes ist necessary to also give them items right from the start, which isnt cost effective anymore.

- last but not least: If you compare Dom 5 with Dom 4 latest patch, there are only a select few new nations( if at all).
Sure, I expect to see quite a some new nations patched in for free over the next years, but still...
Also , all nations basically use the same unit roster as in Dom 4.

All in all I can easily recommend this game to every Domx player and to every player that likes 4 x games like this.
The game is tough to master though and very time consuming but if offers unlimited replayabilty and very, very active MP community . MP games are where this game really shines. BUT I can also recommend this game for players that only be play SP. The dominions series is one of my most favorite one of all time, right after Master of Magic but slightly  ahead of games like HoMM,Age of Wonders,etc..

I would give Dom 5 9/10 rating because I firmly believe most problems will be solved soon.

38033930.review:
I've been a Dominions fan since Dominions 3.  This series is like Master of Magic on steroids with no diplomacy.  It's awesome.  It's also worth noting that this game is actually pretty easy to understand after a while because its systems are incredibly consistent throughout the game design.  Therefore its learning curve is not that bad at all.  So don't be intimidated.  

However, each sequel is more of an incremental improvement on its predecessor than a complete redesign.  Dom5 is the best Dominions experience out there, but it isn't dramatically different than Dominions 4.  It has some welcome new features, great new music, and slightly better graphics, but the underlying game mechanics are the same.  It's not like going from Civilization 4 to Civilization 5, for instance.    

Therefore, I recommend the following:
-If you like Fantasy 4x games, definitely buy this game.  
-If you like 4x games in general, strongly consider this game if Fantasy doesn't turn you off.  
-If you own Dominions 3 only, definitely get this game.  It's a huge upgrade compared to 3.
-If you own Dominions 4, consider waiting for Dominions 6 if you're on a budget.

38001322.review:
Dominions 5 is a fantasy 4x turn-based strategy game where you control one of the pretender gods, you pick a faction and fight other pretender gods for the throne of ascension. By default you won the game once you have defeated all other pretender gods.

Now let's review the game.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Most of the people here said that Dominion 5 is a complex game but for me it's a simple game why? Because of it's high level management. You don't move your every soldier in the battlefield instead they move on their own, your role here is to issue a strategy in pre-battle. Will your cavalery target the rearmost unit? Will your infantry attack the closest unit or large enemy monster? it's all up to you in the strategic screen.

You can see your provinces in the strategic map, the resources, income, recruitment point (which I still don't understand how it's work) and the units you can hire. There are some unique unit in certain provinces like lizarmen, shamblers, mermen, jaguar warriors, etc. You can recruit them but to move unit you have hired to another province, you'll need a commander. Units can only move from province to province by the lead of a commander, once your commander dies your unit will disperse, you'll lose your units. You might regain some unit if you are lucky.

There's a dominion mechanic, it's like spreading your religion. You'll be given a prohet that you picked yourself. This prophet will spread religion of your pretender god not only a prophet a priest can also do the same but it is not as powerful as a prophet. Spreading your religion is important because it expand your dominion, if you have no dominions left you lose the game.

It's just that, simple isn't it?... no need to think tactical, just give high level command and let your unit go crazy. But, it by no means a CASUL game. If you are careless, you'll got rekt and you'll realize it's too late to fix that. Like me, I was focused on building my military but neglected my religion spreading, I got huge military on every province and every nation feared me but my dominions keep decreasing and in the end it's gone completely, I got domkilled.

[h1]Music[/h1]
The music is nice at first but it's repeating. I think it only has one track. I advise to turn off the music and just open youtube and search for epic music, it'll do beter, trust me.

[h1]Artstyle[/h1]
Certainly, dominion games has a minimalist art, 3D for environment and 2-frame 2D sprites for units and characters. For me the art is okay, I can relate to it, I can imagine it. It'll grow on you eventually.

[h1]Score[/h1]
I'll give this game a 8/10, great game.

Vous êtes un fan des jeux type 4X ? Celui-ci est à acheter les yeux fermés (mais genre, vraiment, faut pas s'arreter aux visuels)

Ce que j'ai écris à l'époque sur Dominions 4 s'applique aussi bien sur le 5 :

"Au moins aussi bon qu'il est moche, c'est dire à quel point il l'est ! Ne vous laissez pas rebuter par les graphismes très années 90 (et encore, on trouve des jeux bien plus beau à cette epoque), Dominions 4 est d'une profondeur insoupçonnée. Il ne se laissera cependant pas maitriser si facilement et il sera judicieux de passer par la lecture du manuel (400 pages en anglais) et d'apprendre les raccourcis claviers par coeur, ces derniers permettants d'effectuer des actions qu'aucun bouton in-game ne permet de faire..."

Quand à savoir si les nouveautés justifient un 5ème opus, le débat est ouvert, pour ma part, je le vois comme une version 4.5++, et c'est amplement suffisant pour justifier l'achat.

Combats en temps réél (mais on a toujours "aucun" contrôle direct dessus), une création du prétendant un petit peu plus poussée (au niveau des bénédictions), rendus 3D améliorés (Ah ah, je vous jure), déplacements entre les provinces complètement revu, un vrai cycle saisonnier visuel (mais toujours pas de visuel pour les enchantement darkness), refonte de la génération aléatoire des maps (rien que ça, c'est de la folie, on a des maps générées qui sont... allez j'ose le dire, jolies en comparaison avec celles du 4), et autres joyeusetés au programmes, du tout bon. En revanche, j'ai comme l'impression qu'on a perdu quelques possibilités au niveau des constructions (les routes, entre autres, j'ai pas fait gaffe pour les améliorations des forts), rien de méchant, mais c'est à noter.

De toute façon, il y a bien assez à faire avec la magie, toujours aussi jouissive et démentielle.

Le studio derrière la série Dominions est tout petit, et si ils assurent le même suivi à Dominions 5 qu'à tous leurs autres jeux (ce dont je ne doute absolument pas), vous en avez pour quelques années d'equilibrage et de nouveau contenu (gratuit).

Il y a tant à dire sur ce jeu que ça ne pourra jamais tenir dans une évaluation Steam, mais voyez son solo comme un tutoriel (même si il est tout à fait possible de s'y amuser), il prendra une toute autre dimension en multi, avec des parties pouvant s'etaler sur plusieurs semaines.

37968781.review:
There is a [i]misunderstanding[/i] that this game is overly complex or hard to get into.
Fear not, with a few guide videos on the controls and game concepts (text and video guides are included), you will be able to play fairly well.  Start off with training wheels, then get going consuming the world in the bloody reign of a necromancer or claim the realms of the land with lovecraftian horrors.  I had known of Dom 4 for ages, but was never willing to take the plunge.  It only took a game or two to understand the core mechanics.  

The sheer ammount of content is astounding, and the numbers are not like the Borderlands "500 bazillion guns," most spells, units, blessings, etc. are tremendously different and can have entire strategies developed around them.  I have played as a celestial empire ruled by a shapeshifting astral dragon and a kingdom of norsemen ruled by a race of dwindling elves.  It is the immense quantity of well developed, interesting nations and innumerable viable gods for them that guarantees there is always something new to try.  The nations are based on amalgams of dozens of cultures from throughout history as well as literature and some things that are just downright strange.  Point is there is something, or probably many things, for everyone.

The game is based on a turn based overworld, with variable regions (the random map generator works great and can be tailored to your desired game) and a pseudo-realtime battle replay.  The overworld relies on resource management, the claiming of territory, building construction, exploration, and of course, spreading your dominion.  These concepts are very familiar, just with their own unique flavor.  The combat is all pre-planned, so there is no tactics or direct control.  At first I thought this was offputting, but the forethought and creativity of planning an army and giving it orders, all in advance turns out to be just as fun.  And, if you don't really care, you can just read the results.  Definitely a better autobattle system than Total War.  Like Dwarf Fortress, every unit is fully simulated.  You can watch your units who where lit ablaze, diseased, entangled or crippled limp behind the rest of your army.  Will you care about every archer?  No, but the attention to detail and quality of the simulation is astounding.  Due to the remarkable variety, the interactions of different units can be downright hillarious.  

I know that Dom 4 had a great modding scene as well, including many total conversions.  The game is very mod friendly and allows unbelievably creative maps and units.  The game has a very modular nature, making the possibilites for mods endless and relatively easy to develop.  I look forward to what the community will cook up.  That said, there are a few issues regarding balance and mechanics, but I am not enough of an expert to explain.  It is fun, and if it is too easy, ramp up the difficulty or knock down some of the map generation figures.  No game is perfect, and not on release.  There are also a few UI quirks that don't really make sense or are a bit irritating to use, but none are gamebreaking.

I would highly reccomend this game to anyone who has a bit of an imagination or loves grand strategy/god games.  

[h1]TL;DR:[/h1]  
Everyone is playing hipster pixel art games, but is afraid of elementary arithmetic.  The game is basically what would happen if Limbo/Purgatory was given a kickstarter. 
[b]PROS:[/b]
[list]
[*]There is too much to ever do or understand
[/list]
[b]CONS:[/b]
[list]
[*]There is too much to ever do or understand
[/list]

[b]Жанр:[/b]
Turn Based, Global Strategy

[b]Описание:[/b]
Глубокаяи интересная механика. Вы можете посмотреть на полный перечень статов любого юнита, будто то командир или самое занюханое пушечное мясо. Более того у каждого оружия, брони есть свои показатели. Не будем останавливаться , в игре просто огромное количество контента которое можно изучать месяцами (смотря кто как играет конечно). 
Новая часть лишилась недостатков предыдущих, интерфейс стал еще лучше, проще и доступнее, Добавились новые механики связаные с "благословением",новые состояния, статы, ивенты, бой стал реалтайм и живописнее, смена времен года, замерзающие моря и озера, крепости стали действительно различатьсяиих стены используются стрелковыми юнитами и многое другое.

Редкий представитель кросс-культуры тут вы встретите все кроме высокотехнологичных рас, дарк фэнтези всетаки. Дабы не нудить приведу один из ярких примеров, во многих играх нежить или раса нежити никак не раскрыта и не имеет адекватной геймплейной реализаии. Просто условные "злые" противники, по каким то неведомо магическим причинам вдруг восставшие из мертвых. В Доминионсе все ровно наоборот, есть подробное описание кто откуда, почему и как, более того геймплей за расы нежити очень специфичен. Время играет за вас, смерти мирного населения или простых солдат на руку, бесконечная осада крепости солдатами без морали и нужды в еде, тотальное уничтожение населения и конвертация в нежить,на земле или и воде нет разницы, пока у других жалкие сотни у вас уже тысячи и еще множество нюансов, вроде контр-заклинаний на защиту нежити от изгнания. Прощай кисейная нежить ниочем, только глобальное заклинание старения и все будут станут намного ближе к вам... к истинной смерти.

[b]Геймплей:[/b]
Вы верховный повелитель своей нации, претендент на Бога всего мира, наряду с другими.Сражаетесь заабсолютное доминирование, никакой дипломатии, никих переговоров, только ваша правда и вера должна восторжествовать в этом мире!
Строим юнитов,командиров, задаем параметры построения, поведения, ходим по провинциям, смотрим результаты боя, создаем артефакты для избранных генералов иеще куча нюансов. В лейт гейме это все превращается в рутину, но опытный игрок сведет до минимума время своего хда,исключения только детальная настройка магии для предстоящих крупных боев и расстановка войск.

[b]Недостатки:[/b]
- Упрощенная графика, можно ли считать это недостатком? Возможно простота изображения юнитов инекоторая схематичность присущая серии упрощает восприятие визуальной части игры и не нагружает игрока. 
- "Нужно больше золота" для покупки этой игры. Зато чем дороже тем больше вы её будете ценить :D
- Тяжелый порог вхождения, далеко не все захотят разбираться в этом всём.
- Нет приятного онлайн лобби и других мелочей жизни, но кого это останавливало.

[b]Рекомендации:[/b]
[i]Casual[/i] - сложно и больно, только привозмогая себя.

[i]Normal[/i] - отличный выбор,если не пугает графика.

[i]Hardcore[/i] - хороший выбор и надолго, особенно при условии сетевых оппонентов.

37948788.review:
Домичи 5 продолжают традиции ламповой стратегии, с обвесом из тонны контента, возможностей кастомизации, путей достижения победы, маневров. Я не смогу назвать ни одной стратегии хотя бы приблизительно равной по военным механикам  этой серии. Это игра-наркотик, где даже не особенно хотев сыграть, за пару ходов затянет с головой и ты очнешься спустя многие часы.
  Что же нового приносит пятая часть?
Во-первых мы можем наблюдать доработку движка игры, новые анимации, плавность, оптимизация на голову выше прошлой части. Во-вторых отметим немалое число фич по упрощению менеджмента стратегических маневров в настройках. 
Практически все меню стали куда информативней, явив нативность и давая шанс неофитам вникнуть в процесс куда безболезненней чем раньше. В довесок бои стали динамичней, АИ поправлен, и это чувствуется в действиях подразделений на поле боя. Многие игровые моменты стали логичней, как например гарнизонные лучники в крепостях, вместо крепостных башен автоматического огня, способных безнаказанно выкосить за долгий штурм многие десятки солдат. Теперь ты можешь изощренно выбирать какие блессы получат твои фанатики, какие касты клирики, мой милый претендент. Также отмечу смену погодных условий на стратегической карте, со всеми последствиями для игроков. В итоге серия ничуть не скатилась, а развивается, и что дико редко в наше время - в правильном направлении. Да, это всё тот же особый сегмент игр. Да, вхождение может быть не простым по причине сложностей с английским, неподъёмности на первый взгляд механик. Ну так чего 
еще ожидать после многолетнего отравления казуальщиной?
Открыв для себя домичи однажды, они останутся с тобой навсегда. Однозначно 10 стульев власти из 10.

37947736.review:
Comme Conquest of Elysium, chaque version de Dominions est une amélioration directe du précédent. Ainsi, Dom5 est "plus" et "mieux" que Dom4, mais pas fondamentalement novateur.

Je considère que des patchs pourraient faire pareil, et qu'acheter Dom5 est comme acheter un DLC pour Dom4, vu que c'est quasiment le même jeu, avec des améliorations diverses.

Côté négatif le plus marquant, pour moi : la musique de Dom5 est, sans être mauvaise, bien moins mémorable que celle de Dom4.

Cependant, je sais aussi que pour les 3-5 ans à venir, je vais profiter de mises à jour de corrections, d'équilibrages, et d'ajouts de factions, sorts, créatures... comme c'était le cas pour tous les autres Dom et CoE.

Du coup, ça peut paraitre un peu cher, pour les possesseurs de Dom4, et en même temps, ça permet de soutenir les développeurs qui font un travail sans équivalence sur leurs deux jeux principaux depuis le début du millénaire, pour faine naître et croître le jeu le plus dense du genre.

Donc, pouce en l'air, bien sûr.

37945885.review:
Потрясающая игра и удачное продолжение серии. Если коротко, то это не сложная, но богатая на детали пошаговая стратегия в жанре фэнтези, где игроки выбирают свою фракцию, божество (их более сотни) и ведут их к господству над остальным миром.

Игра делится на 3 эпохи - условно бронзовый век, средневековье и возрождение, каждая из которых уникальна, как силой божеств и магии, так и технологиями, что формируют свой уникальный облик воинов и героев того времени.

Есть три прегенерённых мира разделенных на сотни провинций, каждая из которых уникальна не только биомом, но и народностями, которые там проживают, но есть возможность создать свой собственный, каждый раз уникальный мир, тут и различная поверхность, от океанов, морей, лесов, полей и гор, и подземный мир, и всё это является той или иной благоприятной средой для различных фракций рас, а их тут очень много. При этом, игра замечательно сбалансирована, но опыт игры может сильно отличаться за ту или иную фракцию.

Стратегическая составляющая заключается в том, что вам необходимо захватывать и подчинять провинции, расширяя свои владения, поступление ресурсов, веры и магии. Независимые народности не будут рады вашему вторжению и будут отчаяно сопротивляться, но в конце-концов, ваша кампания расширения территорий, упрётся в границы сопредельного государства, у которого такие же амбиции, и вот тут начинается основная игра.

Что же битв, то в игре более трёхсотен уникальных единиц, обладающих своими способностями, армии возглавляют герои, титаны и аватары богов, а бой можно отдать в руки командиров и ознакомиться с результатом сражения, либо же лично возглавить битву.

Не смотря на архаичный интерфейс, устаревшую графику, игра оставляют потрясающее послевкусие настоящего, олдскульного фэнтези, аля легендарная [b]Birthright: The Gorgon's Alliance[/b].

[h1]Плюсы:[/h1]
[i]+ олдскульное фэнтези
+ увлекательная стратегия
+ глубокая тактика
+ настраиваемый ИИ
+ проработанный мир
+ десятки биомов
+ три различных эпохи
+ множество фракций
+ сотни существ
+ уникальные герои
+ богатая магия
+ случаеные события
+ сюжетные события
+ приятная музыка
+ мультиплеер
+ поддержка модинга[/i]

[h1]Минусы:[/h1]
[i]- устаревший интефейс
- устаревшая графика
- длительность расчётов[/i]

Как по мне, выше обозначенные минусы - не существенны для стратегий таких масштабов.

[h1][b]10 из 10[/b][/h1]

Okay... Sigh... I'm sorry, but as owner of Dominions since Dom 2 I kinda have to say this, and believe me, I know I'm going to get shit for this but~

- Dominions 5 didn't need to exist. The feature list that is here isn't that dynamic, and there isn't much in terms of game changing that would merit a new game. It's unfortunate, because I was really really REALLY hoping that there would be more to this game than there currently is. I was hoping for some early game changes, but saddly I still have some issues. My problem is with large maps, (and I always play large maps) I end up having too much gold and not enough to spend it on. I think it would be great to kill two birds with one stone and allow for more build options on tiles. But~ Then I'm going to get crap in the comments section about how this isn't CIV, and I should go play that. However, I will say that Dominions has the mechanic IN PLACE for building on tiles, but it's never truly been fleshed out, and thats a shame, because it's a really fun mechanic.

- The overall current game Dom 4 plays pretty much exactly the same as Dom 5. Yes, there's some subtle changes here and there with the winter maps now, but... idk... it feels like you could have charged us $15 for a DLC for Dom 4. I'm just saying, we need more changes and addon's to really make this game A NEW GAME. (hell, you could ignore my suggestion altogether, just add more something, make a few more new mechanics) Currently though, I can't recommend this title at the current price tag. That's the worst part of this too, because I really love Dominions, unfortunately there isn't enough here to pay $35 to $40. Buy and play Dominions 4, the mods and maps alone make that game worth the price of admission, Dom 5 though... I'd at least wait a few months to a year, see what can be done for this title before buying.

NOTE: If changes are made latter on, I will update my review to reflect this.

PSS: I included my suggestion in the review because, for large maps this is a problem in the early game. We also see the same old, I've got 40k in gold, but nothing to spend it on because my resources are maxed. These are problems that are not adressed in dominions 5. I'm sure many of you will have your own unique solutions in the comments section. But I'm not changing my review because you don't like what I have to say. I need something more to fix what I feel, is still currently an issue with Dominions. I'm sorry if this rakes some of you on some coals here, but I can not justify giving this game a reccomendation at this time. There isn't much here, it's enough content for a DLC, not enough content for a full game.

37934772.review:
In one game, the city of crystal and bronze is rising from the waves. My people have fled a cataclysm and found refuge under the sea. We tamed the Morvarc'h, fierce sea-horses gallopping over the sea and able to change shape into nightmarish fire-breathing mares. As the priests casts the blessings of our God, a creature composed of the shifting sea herself, the lances of our riders shimmer with holy power and zeal. None can catch our blessed cavalry as it dances around the bulk of our enemy's defense to strike at their leadership while our sorceresses rain down fire, thunder and rain on those poor fools daring to oppose us.

Then, I am human, master of the secret isle of Avalon. Our armies are guided by mysterious witches capable of the forest magic. We summon allies from these forests, for our priests are weak even though our hearts are strong. None can match our skills with the longbow or the cunning of our witches. Their mastery over nature provides us with food, so we can field and supply much larger armies than those of our neighbors.

Now I am a lizard king, long mummified and honoured by my people. Stout warriors of C'tis, some of them. But mostly a rabble of low morale. They break easily, scattering to the neighboring realms. It is for the dead we summon to hold the lines while the sauromancers prepare spells to drain the souls of our enemies, and reanimate them on the spot.


Dominions 5 is about choice and strategy. With countless nations to play, each one very different from the other, and countless tactics for each of these, it's a game with immense replay value.

Players of the series will recognize most nations, and most units. However, the Bless effects have been completely reworked. The random map generator is a piece of art to the point I'll be using it to generate world maps for my tabletop sessions. The nations have been slightly rebalanced. Research has been simplified, and the UI has been made even clearer.

Like every Dominions release before it, it's easily the best of the series. Highly recommended for newcomers willing to get a real strategy game, and for those of us who are playing since Dominions 1.
