37894265.review:
First I'd like to point out that ,while I may have clocked only a handful of hours in Dom4/5 on Steam, that's because the game has no Steamworks DRM (a pro in its own right) and I prefer not to use the Steam client. In actuality, I have played the series since the original, for thousands of hours, and I can't foresee that changing with the fifth iteration.

And there's a good reason for that: unlike most other series, Dominions has been evolutionary rather than revolutionary, and instead of each iteration launching with negative amount of content and mechanics compared to its predecessor, in Dominions the 16 some nations of the original have turned to almost a hundred, on top of added mechanics, modding options and improved user experience. This admittedly does make it "Dominions 4.5" in a sense, but the benefits of this approach are not to disputed and since Dom 5 reworks some of the core systems of the game, the accusations seems very suspect to me. It's also worth pointing out that while some nations remain a bit same-y as they develop over the three playable ages (each with 20-30 nations), there's a great deal of variety between the factions, especially the new ones: there's still a lot of room in the design space to make unique and flavorful nations. And when I say "unique", I mean the degree of difference (in its extremes) analogous to one nation having slow Zerglings as recruitable units, while another fields +3/+3 Ultralisks. And when I say "flavorful", Dominions is a legitimate contender for having the best fluff and worldbuilding in strategy gaming, and as far as I'm concerned, video games in general.

But I digress, let's take a step back and look at what the game is about. You play as a pretender god (a powerful spirit, minion on the previous god, an ancient monster or just a human mage powerful enough to have mastered death) trying to fill the vacancy left behind by mysterious disappearance of the Almighty Pantokrator and aiding you in your quest for Godhood is a nation of loyal followers. Most of the nations are based on real-world mythology or historical nations with fantasy twist and include Tuatha Dé Danann, Zoroastrian birdmen, undead Roman Empire, Spanish Inquisition and Biblical Rephaite giants, and fluff tends to feature detailed mythological references or juxtapositions to real-world history. Dominions is also a very thematic game: An example I like to use is Heart Companions of Arcoscephale (a unit inspired by Sacred Band of Thebes) being canonically gay as they are immune to seduction, but while you can find deviations if you look hard enough, generally speaking mechanics down to combat resolution make thematic sense and when combined with the top-notch fluff (and ability to treat myth and history as expanded universe of sorts), the emergent storytelling potential in Dominions is matched only by the likes of Dwarf Fortress and NetHack.

Mechanically, it wouldn't be utterly wrong to call Dominions 4X, but it's certainly not a typical one and Dominions has more in common with board wargames and their computerized versions so "fantasy wargame" might be a more apt description. The map is province-based, turns are simultaneous and combat takes place during turn resolution based on deployment and scripted orders you can set up in advance with replay of the battle viewable the next turn. This style of combat isn't unprecedented (also seen in games like Frozen Synapse) but especially when you consider the scale (potentially hundreds or even thousands of troops all handled as individuals), it's fairly unique, and besides being a nice change of pace from the more typical omniscient control, it has several key advantages: Predicting enemy tactics and devising a counter in advance becomes paramount and seeing a good plan pay off in a decisive victory is extremely satisfying while anticipating those results is a huge thrill. It more closely captures the decision-making process of a historical commander even if they didn't have magical nukes or battlefield-wide mind control spells at their disposal (or gods fighting on their side). And perhaps most importantly, it enables simultaneous turns, making Dominions extremely well-suited to multiplayer. There is little to no development of provinces and no civilian research: instead, magical research effectively acts as the tech tree that allows you to broaden your strategic and tactical repertoire.

In terms of polish and similar details, I think Dominions by its fifth iteration has reached a good spot, although it obviously is a low production value game. Graphics are perfectly serviceable with clear and easily readable spritework (with a surprising amount of detail on a lot of units if you bother to look) - personally I actually like how the game looks in general despite its undeniably low-tech aesthetic. The soundtrack is solid, although it could use more tracks. Modding doesn't let you alter the core mechanics of the game, but in terms of modding the content, it's very robust and straightforward (plain text files you can edit with the editor of your choice). The UI isn't the prettiest one out there and doesn't adhere to modern ideals but at this point the efficiency is pretty close to local optimum once you figure out the workflow (pro tip: '?' shows all available shortcuts in any given game screen) and I feel it compares just fine against most modern strategy games.

Now that the general description is over, what can I say? Should I focus on actual endgame strategies like indirectly wishing more wishes, breaking dead Titans free from Tartarus and equipping them magical artifacts so as to enable them to wipe out unprepared armies single-handedly, polluting the source of magic with sacrifice of hundreds of virgin girls such that any mage daring to cast a non-blood spell can be detected and tracked by eldritch Horrors, seducing enemy commanders with dryads and then proceeding to rout their leaderless army, or simply buffing your elite troops, making each of them a one-man army? What about discussing the lore in more detail, like how Ermor (Rome) learns death magic from C'tis (Egyptian Lizardmen), inadvertently causing an undead apocalypse and forcing Marignon (Spanish Inquisition) to make a deal with the devil to save the world? Quantity of content (3k+ units, 90 some factions etc)? The multiplayer experience?

Ultimately, it doesn't matter because there's a simpler answer: Dominions has it all. It's undeniably one of the kings of fantasy wargaming, considered one of the greatest strategy/tactics games of all time by many, and at risk of sounding pretentious, I feel it even has value as an "art house game" (ie. you could ignore the exceptional wargame that serves as a vehicle for worldbuilding and simply explore the world the authors have conjured). As of writing this, I have barely touched games other than Dominions 4 for the last half a year, because in my mind they just don't compare, and Dominions 5 seems like a direct upgrade.

The dominions series. I've been a fan since Dominions 3, but, as far as games go, there was a few things that could have been improved.

I'm more than happy to say... It's been DONE.

Major changes from previous version are the combat (not sure it was useful, but it's certainly not detrimental to the game - it helps with cheese "I'm the one that casted the fastest" that was there before though, bonus points here), the recruitment mechanics, and the new bless mechanics.

The recruitment mechanics are awesome. Previously it was good for players to recruit "standard" commanders because it prevented you from recruiting mages. Now, standard commanders can be recruited along with mages. Provinces also have the ability to recruit multiple base commanders.  his is a huge shift in the game as you'll now be able to use the native commanders !

About the new bless effects... Not only there is the possibilty of choosing what effects you want, they also might occur differently depending on province scales ! And there are cross scale blesses too !

Also, smaller point, but... the main menu's been reworked.

One of the deepest and longest running series has just gone better. Fully recommend.

PS: quoted from another review...
"I suggest to activate the multi-turn movement option, as it is great to be able to plan armies movement over several turn, rather than turn by turn."

Ok, it may seems dumb as every other game has had since for ages, but... Dominions hadn't. And now it does. Devs of this game have always been committed but new nations and units had taken most of the attention rather than UI and QoL improvement. I'm happy to see that they focus more on QoL and UI. It was needed.

Another (much needed) QoL that's finally there: national units can now be seen on the nation selection screen INCLUDING the one with terrain recruitment (like the one that can only be recruited in forest for Pangaea for example).

There are probably others.

37854484.review:
Dominions 5 is a fantastic game. For anyone interested in strategy games, especially ones that rely more on thinking than clicks-per-minute, the Dominions series is a must. It's great for intense multiplayer games that span weeks, fantasy and history nerds, and the kinds of players who want to obliterate their enemies with powerful magic. Don't let the graphics fool you - if you're looking for excellent, deep strategy, this is your game. Yes, it's a long learning process, but it's easy to take baby steps and start playing the AI after a quick tutorial. You'll get good later, when you learn about more of the systems. There are plenty of great tutorials on Steam and online that can help you get started, and plenty for more advanced players too. The community actively writes strategy guides and makes whole new nations from mods. It's amazing. Buy it if you're looking for a strategy game where you have to use your head.

That's the pitch for new players. For those returning to the Dominions series, it's a tougher sell. The graphics of the maps are improved, they convey more information, and the randomly-generated ones have new features like rivers and bridges. There's some nice new music. The new bless system is an improvement, both for balance and for creativity. I can't tell yet how much the real-time battle system will affect high-level competitive play, but it doesn't seem to make a big difference in typical situations versus the AI. There have been some small improvements to lowering micromanagement, like the new research system and the option to plot moves that will take multiple turns (I enabled it in Preferences). Other than that (and 3 new nations) not much has changed. $36, or $40, depending on when you read this, is a lot to ask for people who own the very-similar Dominions 4. If I were them, and only played casually and in singleplayer, I'd probably hold off on buying 5 until it went on a meaningful sale, maybe this summer.

While I haven't spent much time with the game yet, I have to say I'm a huge fan of the changes so far from the previous iteration.

Dominions 5 features enough new content to justify paying for the new game, and also boasts some excellent UI and graphics improvements that really make the game more appealing to the average gamer. Although it certainly retains a fairly harsh pixel art look you might be accostomed to from the early 2000s, the UI as well as many other visual elements including some units and things like the icons for the various magical paths have been overhauled and look much better now.

The UI itself is much smoother looking, and although I'm not really a fan of the beta project look of the main menu UI, the UI in every other area is much improved from Dom 4.

The changes to movement, combat, and how bless effects work are what I'm really excited about though. The new bless system is far more flexible and complex than before, and I think will create many more interesting choices in standard gameplay, as well as better options for modding.

The addition of new movement options really increases the number of nations that can actually move one tile at a time, something that felt like it was true of almost all non-flying nations in Dom 4 due to the prevalence of alternate terrain.


I'll add to this as I test out more stuff, but as a huge fan of Dom 4 coming into the next game, I'm really happy with the changes.

37833226.review:
If you like Dominions 4, you should buy Dominions 5. If you don't like Dominions 4, you should not buy Dominions 5. If you never played Dominions 4 at all, you should think long and hard before buying this game.

Not that it's a bad game. Far from it, it's a fantastic game once you get into it. But it's one of those games that's simply not meant for everyone. If you need high-quality graphics in your games, forget about it. If you need a cinematic experience, forget about it. If you need a good story in your games, forget about it. If you need a game that you can just pick up and play, forget about it. If you need a game that'll slowly teach you how to play as you move along, forget about it. If you need a game that requires no effort, forget about it. If you need a game that rewards your effort in any way other than the thrill of victory, forget about it.

If you're ready for a game that requires you to take your time, learn, think, and plan. If you're ready for a game with literally hundreds of races, units, spells and items and it doesn't even have the decency to tell you which ones are good and which ones are bad. If you're ready for a game that at times will leave you disgusted and frustrated, or suck up hundreds of hours of your life, or even both at the same time. If you're ready for a game which promises nothing but hollow offline matches against a barely-capable AI and maybe the glory of a few online victories if you even get that good... Then sit down, and prepare to enter the magical realm of Dominions 5.

37832555.review:
I am this kind af player that waits for years after the release of a game before buying it, during some sale, but not this one : Dominions 5 is the first game I bought Day One.

I was introduced to the series with the 3rd game, and played it for hundreds of hours. Then again for the 4th. And now it is time for the 5th.
The changes between each are subtle, but make a huge difference when you switch back to the old one.



In Dominions 5, you play as the god of a nation, ranging from primitive, loincloth-wearing men-bats armed with clubs to ice giants, pious knights or even toad-fishes lurking the depths. You have to manage the military, magic and religious aspects of you empire, and have to get rid of evildoers (aka anyone that does not worship you)

This game will not take you by hand : you will have to put an effort to learn the game by yourself, although tutorial video are now available on the game's website. But most subtilities will be learned with time playing, and you will have to develop your own strategies to beat independants, IAs, and finaly other humans. You will learn not to rely on your troops but rather on your mages, take into account the ever-present randomness and overcome it, and adapt to any situation given your more or less limited options.

Last but not least : contrary to a lot of strategy games, you cannot control your troops during battles, and must carefully plan their positions and orders prior to combat, whereas many unexpected events will disrupt your well-oiled strategy. Hence my remark on randomness.

I flat out love the Dominions series - standard go to game when AAA products fail to impress.  There's as much content in this game as in the entire Mass Effect series, and not a single microtransaction.  =P

Dominions games aren't about graphics, though they are getting better with each edition - an improvement on standard roguelikes, anyway.  They are very much about deep strategy and deep lore with fantasy drawn from history.  Do you want to be an evil overlord of baby eating giants whose blood slave virgins are rescued by a troll hero's adventuring party?  Do you want to lead a righteous inquisition with flagellants willing to martyr themselves while a host of angels descend (and perhaps some nastier thing ascend) to fight for your cause?  Does the idea of trying to blot out the sun while a volcanic race is trying equally hard to make it grow seem appealing?  Then this is the game for you.

I've put a ton of hours into the single player, which alone is a great experience.  If you're thinking about the stellar multiplayer, I'd suggest Youtube searching Nuclearmonkee / The Elephant Whisperer.

Buy with confidence.

37830282.review:
What a jewel! This game is deeper than deep - it is vast. In my humble opinion it is the best fantasy strategy game I know and one of the best strategy games in general. 
Why?
You have near endless stragic possibilities, a deep nation setup based on the countless myths of our planet (celtic, german, indian, mayan, greek roman, middle eastern, northern, chinese, japanese and many more) and the battles need your tactical brilliance.
It is a world to dive into. Join the growing community and learn about myths, strategic brilliance and tactical finesse. You'll have a steep learning curve but you will enjoy a deep experience like no other.

So what is new in dominions 5 compared to previous titles of the series? Apart from a great new soundtrack (really beautiful), better graphics, an improved random map generator, further content (like new units and nations, random events, etc.), improved user interface, a new combat system was implemented (now real time and thus more realistic battles) and many inner mechanics were overhauled, streamlined and in my view perfected.

One example of these changes is the complete overhaul of the bless system. The mighty being you play in this game in your strive to godhood blesses his sacred followers (the priests and holy units (mages/commanders/warriors) of your nations. How these blesses function and what they do was streamlined. But also the mechnics were improved. For example that the most powerful blesses only work on your faithful sacred minions when you, the god pretender, is alive (when you die in game you can be called back by your priests what costs time) is new and makes perfect sense as well as keeping your pretender alive even more important than in Dominions 4 and before. 

Another (minor) example is the unit log that you now have. The game keeps track of the actions every unit in the game did in the unit tab. So if you have one of your heroes or mighty summoned beings or even a "lowly" slave unit that you feel close to your heart (as it by chance chopped off the head of the mighty scorpion king that tried to pillage your jucy high income province :)) you can browse through his history and see what he did throughout the game in your glorious conquest.

The two guys behind of illwinter that are the creators of the Dominions series (backed by a growing and decdicated community) have shown in the past that they continuosly improve their products (Dominions and Conquest of Elysium series mainly) for many years. Its predecessor Dominions 4 has up to now 31 updates, fixing bugs, polishing the game (ai etc), delivering new nations, units, spells and so forth. This is more than good support to say the least. Thus, do not hear to people telling you that just a few things changed and that Dominions 5 is just a Dom 4 plus that costs a bunch of money. That's not true. It is worth every PENNY!

See you around as Zeus, a fourth armed Indian Goddess of destruction, a giant squid in the sea or in whatever embodiemened you chose to claim for ascension. ;-)

And now excuse me - I,  Tauron, Master of the Rock, the Hidden One, Nourisher of the fields (the game gives you names depending on how you design your pretender being) must return to my holy and rigthous cause to banish all other Pretenders to become - you know what.

The Dominions series has been steadlily improving in terms of game concepts and game interface since the very first game, and now with Dominions 5 it is more polished than ever.  But the polish doesn't obscure any of the wonderful facets of the game at all.  Highly recommended.

The venerable series returns with upgrades in several areas. First, bless effects are available when setting up your pretender god. The random map generator has been improved, and the graphics for the map and interface are much clearer, upgraded for higher-resolution displays. Recruitment points are now required for obtaining units (in addition to money and resources). The non-interactive combat is now “real-time”, where simultaneous actions (like moving and shooting) can occur at the same time. The fantastic core gameplay remains: choose one of the many nations, design your pretender god, expand by attacking surrounding provinces containing magic sites, defend new territories with a garrison to keep unrest low, build forts to collect nearby resources, spread dominion with temples and preaching, construct labs to research new spells, cast local and global rituals, recruit new units and hire mercenaries, set up army formations and battle orders, equip leaders with magical items, watch automated battles, and try to survive against the very capable AI. Much like its predecessor, Dominions 5 is more like an incremental upgrade, but overall it is a fantastic, feature-filled strategy game.

Dominions 5 is arguably the richest fantasy strategy wargame ever made with 86 factions, 200 gods, 3000+ unit types, 8 magic paths, 500 battle spells, 400 ritual spells, 77 bless effects, 300 unit perks, 400 craftable items, 1000+ magic sites to discover, 3000+ random events, and randomly generated maps.

All beautifully represented with loving detail (e.g. every unit has unique flavor description) and now with full battle logs and stats for every single unit and a history playback of your game. This is a strategy gamer and role-player's dream.

Dominions replayability is practically endless and you'll likely find yourself playing for years. Dominions is one of those games that never leaves your PC.

Having said that, Dominions does have a steep learning curve but there is a complete PDF manual as well as video tutorials to help get you started. If you can get past this initial time investment you will be richly rewarded with some deep, memorable gaming experiences.

Dominions 5: Warriors of the Faith is the sequel to Dominions 4: Thrones of Ascension.
Both are unique games that once you put you're foot in them you get stuck in an endless quagmire of mechanics, strategy and diplomacy (when you play multiplayer, the AI is dumb as bricks, just can't handle the complexity of the game).

Dominions 5 brings multiple new and interesting systems to the table, notably an entirely new customizable Blessing system where you can decide what powers the holy warriors of your Pretender God are granted when a priest of the true faith blesses them with your God's powers as well as a revamped fort building and commander recruitment system.

I heartily recommend the game for anyone who wants to think hard and long about how many wizards to send and what you want them to cast while summoning demons from the nether realms or contacting the Angels and Harbingers of the One True God.

37778382.review:
*Bill Duke voice*

You know what I like best?

The price.

*Drives out through the window of Illwinter's office and escapes down the highway*


Well what can I say? Every new instalment in the Dominions series is an expansion on the last and so there's really no reason to stick with any of the prequels. Because of this, everything that I said in my lengthy Dominions 4 review still stands. Dominions 5 is a polished and expanded version of Dominions 4.

I was initially skeptical that the game would be worth the £30/$40 for me, as someone who owned Dominions 4. Having now played the game, I can safely say that my skepticism has been washed away and that I'm very glad that I bought the game the instant that it was released (and there was never any doubt that I would).

Dominions 5 continues the series tradition of being on an extreme end of the graphics versus gameplay scale. Namely the end that cares little about the visuals and everything about depth of gameplay. This is what makes the Dominions series so special and why myself and most other fans love it. And I say that as a relatively new recruit, having only discovered the series with Dominions 4. However, Dominions 5 has received a high degree of polish in the visual department and looks markedly better than its predecessor.

There are new nations, new events, and everything else that you'd expect from a Dominions sequel, including new features that only someone who knows the Dominions series can truly appreciate. For example, your characters will now make their own way to a destination without you having to micromanage them through every province. I'm not joking when I say that such a feature alone would make Dominions 5 tempting to me, and I didn't see anyone even mention it in the run-up to release. Dominions 5 seems to emphasise playing on random maps more than its prequel did, and they look utterly gorgeous compared to how they did in Dominions 4. What I personally love is how you can prevent random maps from wrapping around in every direction now. Of course if you've never played a Dominions game before that won't mean anything to you. But trust me, it's a good thing. The new music is gorgeous too.

To be honest, I just wanted to give the game the good review it deserves—I didn't really plan to say much. It's Dominions again and it's better than before. The trailer for the game claims that it's the deepest strategy game of all time, and that's no idle boast. I've been gaming for nearly thirty years now and I've never played anything that comes close to Dominions in terms of tactical depth and strategic potential.

If you're a fan of turn-based strategy at all, then the Dominions series is essential. You won't be able to understand its depths without reading the manual or asking for help on the forums, and even then you'll be pretty clueless for your first few games, but believe me, Dominions is a series that amply rewards perseverance. I myself am still learning, and I'm loving every minute of it.

Now excuse me, I must lead the nation of Atlantis across the bottom of the ocean so that I can spread the good word of our god, Kronos, across the lands of men from the safety of our underwater temples.

Oh, and I was just joking with the opening. Illwinter Game Design consists of two guys (Johan Karlsson and Kristoffer Osterman) who're responsible for not only the Dominions games, but also the Conquest of Elysium series. They probably make their games while sitting in their underpants in their living rooms. I know I would. I'd be surprised if they had an office, nevermind one with a window big enough to drive out of.

40750988.review:
If you are new to dominions, this game is amazing. 

You are a pretender god, one of the many gods vying to become the sole God of the world. You start with one race that worships you, and each race is totally unique from demon ogres, skeleton undead, ethereal undead, elves, magmamen, frogmen, illithids, humans, giants, ogres, cyclops, lizardmen and beastmen, among at least 10 other nations (there are roughly ~20 completely different races, but if you throw nations that have similar racial units but different practiced magic (Fire human mage nation versus water human mage nation), you easily have 30+ nations.

It's an indie game with indie graphics, but it has the deepest turn-based (PBEM) multiplayer mechanics I've ever seen in any strategy game. It has insane nation and strategic customization, and the  pretender design, research targets, combat scripting choices, and gem use strategy result in a game that is filled to the brim with meaningful player choices and decision.

It's also a game that's filled with lore. Each unit has several sentences or paragraphs of description, from the individual trooper to commanders and special summons.

It's a game that is full of simulation. Literally everything is simulated in the game: age, old age afflictions, permenant wounds, disease, commander ability, morale, formations, magic resistance, elemental resistance.

If you're a dominions 4 veteran, I highly recommend dominions 5 because the new bless and pretender design system is much deeper than before, and because they significantly sped up gameplay with the overall halving of siege defense. I didn't play much dominions 4 because it felt slower than dominions 3, but I'm thrilled to say dominions 5 is sped back up.

Overall, you can't go wrong if you are turn-based strategy lover and are open to indie, PBEM MP games.

40643531.review:
I am new to Dominions, but I have been aware of the franchise for a while, always passing over it because of the graphics. Huge mistake. I have been a fan of Crusader Kings II, Civilisation and Masters of Orion for a long time and I am astonished to say that this game burries tham all. 

Dominions is perhaps the most complex game I have ever seen, yet it is equally elegant in it's easy to master interface. The options in this game are truely unlimited in their variety and combination, but every new choice comes as something to be investigated and discovered, rather than some hidden stumbling block preventing you from getting ahead. Don't get me wrong, you will want to watch a tutorial or read the manual before you get into it, but this is a testiment to the truly unique game play which is at once reminisent of so many classics and totally original in every way. 

At first Dominions is intimidating with its laundry lists of skills and statistics, but every strength and weakness is represented in the descriptions and lore, allowing you to reliably ignor the numbers and read the text to figure things out. What's more is that every element in the game is based on something from mythology or litrature, infact it was after discovering a reference to Kipling that I decided I had to write this review. If you are like me, and love history and can't get enough of table games like Risk or Settlers this game is a must own. 

No description or review can do this game justice, it really must be experienced to be belived. And those graphics? Once everything is in motion they are actually captivatingly beutiful, with every element a symbol carrying information about the armaments of units or compositions of enemy armies. Honestly, 3D models or flashy map effects like Civ and Age of Wonders would be nothing more than a confusing distraction in Dominions. The game is a master work, and is clearly the product of decades of dedication by it's developers who I would cautiously describe as the Van Goghs of game design after experiencing their work.

I have only been playing for a few weeks as of writing this, and I know as an internet stranger my opinion doesn't count for anything, but do yourself a favour, invest in a game that needs no steam sale or advertisments. Still don't belive me? Then take the word of this unimpeachable religious wacko in the most inexplicable game review on the internet: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ed3Gvjpp9Ns 

Why are you still reading this and not having reincarnated monkeys summon demons from the underworld through blood sacrifice?

40561354.review:
They rewrote the game on a new engine and it shows. Far better performance compared to Dominions 4. Battles are now in real-time rather than turn based. Multiplayer connections are more stable. And of course, there is new content as well. A handful of new nations, and a bunch of new spells and items.

The reworked bless system is appreciated. Rather than having to commit 4 or 9 points into a single path to unlock effects, you now have more varied options with stronger and weaker blesses available.

The game is very nice so I'm willing to look past its shortcomings, which are:

-The new OST is a nice change of pace, however it's my personal opinion that the previous game's OST fits the theme of the game better.

-The recruitment point mechanic doesn't add anything to the game.

-Balance - The devs have made great strides in balancing this game compared to Dominions 4. The almighty Rain of Stones trap is no more. Many nations have been buffed and nerfed based on player feedback. They even recently buffed the new nation Mekone in the short span of time after its release. 
But there are still clear winners and losers.
If you really want to play a specific nation, then you have to proceed knowing full well that you may not be playing on even ground.

Overall, a great game and worth the relatively high price for an indie game.

40524017.review: Devs continue to update and add to the game!

40501799.review:
I started playing IllWinter games with Conquest of Elysium 3, and have been hooked on that and the Dominions series ever since.  


LIke many others have said more eliquently, and with better spelling, this is a no-brainer purchase if you have any love for deep strategy games.  It is easily the most complex and thoroughly thought out game I've ever played.  

It has more factions than you can ever hope to master, and each has both a deep and often historically relevant or fantastical backstory, and an individual playstyle.  You can play as Undead Romans, Eagleman Zororastrians, Bloodthirsty Aztecs, Lizard Egyptans, Giant Vikings, Japanese Demons, Cananite Monsters, Lovecraftian Illithids, Conan-Inspired Barbarians. There is even a race i think is based on the children's story Where the Wild Things Are.  It never stops.  There are so many units, spells, and items that the strategic depth is basically limitless.  While the game is pretty balanced, they don't fall prey to the god of balancing, as some factions are purposely stronger or weaker to give the game added flavor and realism.  The modding community is super active and I haven't even started playing multiplayer as I still get whooped by anything over Mighty, but I'm getting there.  


They add factions without DLC.  They add factions for free.  They have added 3 or 4 full factions since Dominions 5 came out.  Some people felt Dominions 5 was a glorified update of Dominions 4, but it added simultaneous movement in battles which really changed the game significantly, and of course they added a bunch of new factions for Dom5, changed the tax system (removing a micro-headache) and changed the bless system (made it much better, much more strategically deep).  


I think most would agree that each update is well thought out and adds to the game without breaking things.  They update the game about once a month or every other month.  They are thorough updates.  they don't go more than 3-4 updates without adding a new faction (or two with the latest one).  


I've owned both Dom 4 and Dom 5 on Steam and I still haven't even PLAYED all the factions yet.  there are like at least 80, they may be up to 90 by now.  It CRAZY! Plus there are many dozens of additional factions made by modders.  

There is no learning "curve"  You never stop learning.  I don't think the game can ever truly be mastered.  

But you get a feel for the rhythm of the game over time.  There are 3 distinct phases to the game, early expansion, the middle game, and the end game, and they each play quite differently, your faction may have advantages at one stage but become vunerable during another, and you have to play accordingly.  you have to balance research, troop recruitment, conjuration, item production, dominion spread, blood hunting, etc.  Some factions kill off their population on purpose and just use magic or necromancy to develop armies.  You can kit up superunits that can kill whole armies on their own. it's really just endless fun. There are even three ages that you can play the game in, where the factions evolve and technology and access to magic changes, later age armies have more armor and deeper but more narrow magic pathing, lower magic resources, better fortresses etc.  They give you lots of starting options though, you can play late age with lots of magic sites and super fast research if you want, you can start with 1 province or up to 9 if you want, etc etc etc. 


The graphics are 2D sprites, but are full of information about what the unit can do.  Can your unit throw a javelin before charging into melee? The sprite carries a little javelin.  Is your unit a size 6 giant with 60 HP?  He towers over the size 2 human units as he should (careful giant, you're easily surroundable!)  Is your unit a cave man in fur clothes carrying only a club.  check.  Can your merman grow legs when on land? done.  The graphics are just a functional as the rest of the game.  


Did I mention injuries? Your unit can be one shot with a good lick to the head, can loose an eye from a well placed arrow (and it will affect is attack ability), can lose a leg and be crippled (but still fight on).  He can take a chest wound that never fully heals, permanently reducing HP.  Morale is also very well modeled, troops definatly get less enthuastic as the battle progress, and fatigue is modeled as well.  

Your Pretender God can die, and be prayed back into existence.  You can blood sacrifice to strenghen you God's power over enemy territory.  You can pray another faction literally to death.  You can summon demons, you can mark enemy units to be targeted the the horrors of the void. You can effectly raid with stealthy units, or flying units, or conjured units.  you can blot out the sun, you can poison the entire battlefield, you can poison your enemy's provines, or send a hurricaine there. you can wish. You can raise the dead. If you're a lizard nation, some of your undead will be little undead lizard men.  the little things add up.  


Ok, so buy the game, support this development team, they are a true gem.

40493718.review:
I have been playing the Dominions series since the third game. And I am absolutely in love with the franchise. The diversity, the options, the fact that every nation actually plays differently, rather than being the same thing with slight varients...

But one of the things that sold me the most is how much the games improve with each iteration. It doesn't feel like you're changing the game, it feels like you're taking what's already there and making it better. improving the UI, making it more realistic, which really appeals to me. It's like the Malazan Book of the Fallen of Fantasy video games... and gives that touch of fantasy realism that really helps with immersion.

I am by no means a "hardcore gamer" and recognize that a lot of the game stuff goes over my head, or I don't take the time to do properly. But it's one of those games that you can at least muddle along pretty well without spending hours optimizing and min-maxing. The option is there, but it's not a requirement.

I love the new bless system, making your gods even more customizeable to your specifics, which really appeals to me. I was hesitant about the simultanious combat at first, but it REALLY increases immersion to see it go all at once, plus it helps resolve battles much faster, especially with large fights, or ones with a ton of mages.

and all the updates that have come out since then? Fixing bugs, balancing things, ADDDING NEW NATIONS? listening to the community and trying to make this game as good as possible? 40448000.review:
I've been playing since the Dom 3 days, spending literal thousands of hours playing the various iterations of this game, both SP and MP. This series stands alone as the most complex, in-depth, and intentionally quirky strategy game experience on the market... for those who enjoy multi-dimensional statistics, learning at a moutainously steep up-curve, and using your own imagination to flesh out the spaces inbetween the lines... there's not many other choices.

 I.E. in what other game series can you be the blood-hungry death-god of an Aztec-esque race of bat-men led by ancient demons with "a human torso, the legs and paws of a jaguar and head and wings of a bat. It feeds on still beating hearts and its gruesome appetites cause unrest and discontent." and then have mechanics built into the game where each one of those units causes unrest to go up by a certain level in whichever province it's in, which you then have to patrol with an army to decrease, which in-turn causes the population of that province to go down a few (representing the unruly people that had to be killed to quell the unrest), which depending on how much unrest was in that province, can in-turn lower your income?

This is definitely a niche game... I don't need to elaborate on graphics or UI deficiencies when compared to modern mainstream interest games, others have already done that extensively... 

For those of us who refuse to compromise character for mass-appeal, Dominions is the only True choice.

Any new content feels very thin on the ground and pretty much gets lost due to how big the game is.  

They also removed the ability to defend on the tactical battlefield, armies are forced to charge each another after 2 combat rounds.  This removed alot of strategy / tactical aspects of the gameplay which made it so much fun to play.  far less play, counter play now.  

They have gone backwards on buildings, removing the option of upgrading your forts as you want, to a more generic ssytem.

You only get a couple of maps to start off with, which obviously soon becomes boring.

To sum up, I think Dom 5 shows that Illwinter have run out of good ideas to implement in the Dominions series and thus resorting to mass nerfs, intoducing poor mechanics.  Also, they seem not to be putting much new good stuff into the game, like new spells, items, new abilities, new unique nations etc.  They seem to be concentrating on 'realism' and tiny mechenisms that no one is hardly ever going to use.  Need to concentrate more on gameplay and just making it fun to play, not constantly increasing micro-management, making it harder for new players to understand, making everything harder to use in general.

40199668.review:
Overall, I like the idea of the game: It is the same as Dominions 4:  you are a pretender god that rules a civilization and must become the god by multiple conquest options conquering special territories: the Thrones of Ascension, eliminate all oposition, or by conquering a number of territories.

Another very strong point is the "lore"... Every culture and unit have a fantasy lore, inspired in traditional folclores, such as indian, or even Lovecraftian cultures... I believe you can download the manual so you can take a look... And each culture have a quite unique strategy for playing... 

If you want a game with exceptional artwork, and friendly interface... Well... Go somewhere else. If you want a game with an astounding quantity of options and strategies, and you are not afraid of spreadsheets and to read a 382 pages manual, keep reading...

The game have a very complex mechanic: for starters, an army is composed of commanders, that would be very similar to "heroes" on other games: special individuals that can lead up to a number of undead, magical or normal units. And then they have units, that represents individual soldiers. These soldiers may be maimed, crippled, mortally wounded, beheaded... You archers can kill your own men... And battles are decided entirely by the computer, based on orders you specify before the battle begins: you control the position and formation of squads, and the initial 5 orders for commanders, and a general directive, such as advance and cast spells.

A battle may be decided even before it starts: it is the morale of the troops what ultimately decides a battle, not necessarily what do you kill... If you kill a commander, the squads this commander leads will rout. The challenge here is how to reach the commander, if you can't identify where the commander is: there is no way to tell the units to "kill the commander"... You can tell the units to attack the rearmost units and hope the commander is there...

The user interface is lacking... And this starts building up as the game advances... This makes the game be played in two ways: for people who like to micromanage , like myself, this becomes a pain, that ends up making me quit the game after 20 or 25 turns: there is no easy way to account for the units you have, the leaders you have... you can't see the provinces with different sort orders... To organize your troops, you need commanders... and organization can be very complex: there are shortcuts for some actions, but the complexity of the game itself make you want to see some more complex queries than simply select all units of the same type at a single stack... You can see all my wishlists in the forum. 

But you can see in the videos people enjoying the game simply by ignoring most of the mechanics, and building an army or killer pretender and jumping from province to province, hoping for the best... Playing the game completely "by the ear"... and using logics like "militia = bad; Monolith = deadly; Poison slingers = good".

This game , due to it's play-by-email structure, would be great if there was some openness for automation... It should marry screeps  ( https://screeps.com/) and make little Screepinions puppies.

This game doesn't have a lot of the graphical bells and whistles of 90% of games out there but it more depth, fun and replayability than 90% of games out there. 40122889.review:
Dominions 5 is an excellent free-for-all or single player experience whose deep strategic systems and vast options allow for great player expression through gameplay.  Building up a nation and crafting a strategy with the many unique faction units, magic spells, and bonuses is great fun.

My primary discontent with this game is that it's combat systems are bad for CO-OP and team games.  As someone who enjoys teaming up with friends to tackle difficult AI challenges or even other players the mechanics make allied coordination difficult and often counter productive.

In short, Dominions 5 is a strong game for fans of "Grand Strategy", but an extremely weak co-op experience.

40066954.review:
Honestly its weird, because i am a huge fan of the dominions series, and the 5th game did bring some very essential and nice changes like a cool looking winter update, so that you now can see on the maps which maps are cold provinces and which are not, so that you can plan your mapmovement around frozen rivers and other nice stuff that involves mostly around some obious unbalanced stuff in dom 4

So why do i give the game then a thumps down? 
Well because they introduced a new feature that destroys every chance to find a balanced state.

How do you balance a game that has hunderts of nations in it? The easy and obious anser is of course: you dont. Big companys balance their games for years to find a good balance between 3-5 nations and even some very "basic" games like chess where it seems that their is only one "nation" that the white side has a slight advantage over the black side. 

But the developer where quite active and tried their best to balance certain obious stuff in patches over the days, and also i never mindet the lack of perfect balance of the game, because of the many opportunitys that you could do, the lategame magic spells that you can research, so that it always feeled in the lategame, that if you loosed than your opponent just was able to put out cooler tactics out of his sleves and that he deserved the win. The variety of possible choices in the later state of the game where the  thing that made the game so awesome to me. 

But there was always one play-style i did not like a all: The bless strategie. 

For explanation: A bless strategie is a tactic in which you are able to increase the strenght of your sacred units, your strongest units that you can regulary recruit and only in smaller numbers per turn, immensly from the start. This is in theorie quite interesting, because the more magic scales you choose for your pretender, the worser your scales, that affect your income of gold or ressources and other stuff, will be. 

But this was always a very "dirty" tactic for me, since i have seen this tactic in action by myself in my first MP game, since it gives a huge advantage to nations that have already strong but expensive sacreds, since the limit of a few per turn doesnt affect them, if their sacreds are already so expensive that they couldnt recruite more of them, even if they wanted. And nations of which the sacred warriors are just stronger regular units, from which you could recruit 100 per turn if you whould be allowed, have a massive dissadvantage. 

But even so it was balancable, since the strongest blessings where locked behind a magic path of 9, which means that a player who wanted to go for the popular double bless strategie, had to invest massive points into his pretender to boost 2 magic paths to 9 to get the required blessings. 

But in dom 5 the developer thought that this "mass to magic path 9" pretender building was somewhat boring so they implemendet a total new blessing system in which you have to choose from many many blessings you can choose from. So with fire 7 you can either buy the most expensive but most likely also strongest blessing, the Awe, and nothing else, or many minor blessings. But because you can choose now from so many different blessings to the already so many different nations...it just became totally unbalanced and for me unfun. 

For example must pick for strong but expensive sacred troops were always regeneration, which gives them 10% of their health back every turn. 
A white centaur of Pangaea for example can increase his HP easly to 31 from which on he will regain 4 health every turn...what is around 50% of the most units health. But now they can buff this already very hard to kill centaur with other blessings like the ethernal blessing, which not only makes them regain 4 HP every turn, but also let them become almost impossible to hit for the most regular troops, which allows a very small number of them to crush through 100 regular soldiers or more without problem.

Or lets take a looks at the sacred troops of Ashdod. Their sacred giants start already with 50 HP, so a little HP boost of 1+ Regeneration allows them to regain 6 HP per turn...which is massiv. But now only that, but as strong armored giants they also have a very high protection...but with the new blessing system there is a bless called "stygian flesh" which increases the protection against every weapontype by 10...which boost their sacred warriors to a total protection of 25 and the other sacred warriors even to 28. This huge protection value makes it impossible for the most warriors to even make a slight wound, but with the regeneration of 6 HP per turn, it is not already almost impossible to hurt them at all...but even if someone can make a lucky hit and hurt the giant for 1 HP, he will just regain it in one turn. Which makes these giants not hard, but totally impossible to kill for the most nations that have not elemental weapons on their regular troops or special attacking units that dont care about the high protection value. And not only for the first years, but really until the lategame where you have gain very strong spells that can deal with them. 

And this is why i dislike the new blessing system so uppermost. While the game was never balanced, their was always something to do in the lategame, so that it always feeled, that if you loose that your opponent outplayed you, and that he deserve the win and you deserve the loose since their are so many ways how you could play differently which would let you be better prepared to the enemy. 

But since the research that allows you the variety of playstyles with your magic has to be researched first, while the overwhelming blessings of the sacred units start already with turn 1, every MP game becomes a gambling, since the only way how to counter a strong-blessing nation...is to be a strong blessing nation yourself. But if you are not...then you are under the mercy of the blessing nation and can only pray that he lets you live, and attack other nations first, until you have enough research done that you can counter the sacred troops. 

And this feels just so unfair, that at least for me, i now have to check every nation that in the game i want to play with if their is a nation, that has access to strong but expensive sacreds, that can overwhelm everything you can throw at them in many game-years to come, since nations like this will at least for me destory every fun i had in the past games of dom 4, since seeing a small troop of sacred units that cost a few hundret gold destroy a full army of yours, that cost thousends of gold and takes many turns to recruit...is just not fun nor does it feeled that the opponent did just outplayed you, since its more like "well he has access to strong sacred units and i have not...GG" 

I really hope that the next installement of dominions will throw this new bless system, that sounds cool on paper but is aweful in reality, out, so that the games will really be decidet once more who can react to the tactic of the enemy the most, and not who can build with his sacred troops the strongest warriors.

39932774.review:
2018/02/08

[h1]大まかな評価[/h1]
※5段階評価
[b]グラフィック　　：★
サウンド　　　　：★★★★★
操作性　　　　　：★★
ゲームボリューム：★★★★★
雰囲気　　　　　：★★★★★
ゲームパフォーマンス：★★
[/b]

Dominionsシリーズ初心者ではありますが、良い点や気になった点を書いていきたいと思います。長文になりますので、つまみながらでも読んで頂けると幸いです。


◆総評
[h1]＊万人にはオススメ出来ないが、脳内妄想が好きな人向けの作品＊[/h1]
昔ながらのチープなグラフィック、しかし内容は現在のゲーム以上に素晴らしい出来。しかし敷居としては若干高く、ビジュアルも含めとっつきづらい。ロールプレイには最適かも。

敷居が高いという点に対しては、日本語Wikiが充実＋Dominions日本人Discordコミュニティがあるので、わからないことがあればすぐ聞くことが出来るため少し下がってきています。
日本語化modも鋭意作成中との事なので、更にこのゲームがとっつきやすくなるハズです。

ゲーム本体のアップデートやModアップデートにより、遊びやすく/楽しみやすくなっているので、このゲームが気になっている方は是非購入してみては如何でしょうか。


◆補足
敵1900vs自国200　の戦闘を動画に撮ってみました。なんかこう、少数精鋭で大多数の敵を跳ね返すっていうのは展開として燃えます！
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bMudwDVpXko



[h1]＊これ、何するゲーム？＊[/h1]
ゲームの基本構造は、CivilizationやAge of Wondersのような自分の国で生産したユニットで敵を倒しプロヴィンスを支配し、領地を占領していくという流れです。更にこのゲームのもう一つの勝利条件として、マップ上に散らばっている”昇天の玉座”（Thrones of Ascension）を獲得するという手もあります。

[h1]＊要するにターン制ストラテジーとちゃうんか？＊[/h1]
ゲームの根幹としてはそうだと思います。しかし、Dominionsで圧倒的に他のゲームと違う点として
[b]戦闘の規模[/b]
[b]生産ユニットの種類[/b]
[b]国の指導者＋国家の組み合わせ[/b]
上記三点が上げられます。
この特徴が生み出す効果として「勝利条件に達するまでのアプローチ方法の幅が非常に広い」という点が上げられます。

例えばAoW3。ウィザードの場合、最強の召喚獣を大量に召喚して敵をなぎ倒すのがセオリーです。
例えばHoI4。ファシスト化→道路国家を通過し→ソ連を倒して満足。（コレに関しては複数の目標があるので割愛）
等、ある程度のセオリーが存在するのがストラテジーゲームですが、このゲームにはそういったセオリーが存在せず、相手の国家やユニットの組み合わせに対して臨機応変に対応しなければいけません。

「対応」というよりは「対策」が近いかもしれません。イメージとしては「日本列島にゴジラが出現し、対策本部を設置してやんややんやと会議を行う首脳陣」です。

”ユニット数が膨大な為、ユニットの組み合わせによっては強敵になる得る”
グール1000体 / グール800+騎兵200体 / 魔術師5人+グール500+騎兵200+召喚獣300等など、これらの組み合わせに対して適切に対処を行わなければ、自分が頑張って生産したユニットが蹂躙され、首都まで攻め込まれることでしょう。

上記のような敵の編成に対して頭を悩ませ、ユニットの戦闘時配列や戦闘時の行動命令を考え、ユニットを効率よく生産し結果を予測するのもこのゲームの醍醐味だと思います。

厄災のように襲いかかる敵をはねのけ、勝利条件を目指すゲームとなっています。


[h1]＊ほーん、組み合わせにテンプレが無いって事？＊[/h1]
先の例では戦闘ユニットを上げましたが、このテンプレートが無いというのは国家にも当てはまります。このゲームは
①自分が使用する国家を選び
②国家の指導者（神）を”作成”し
③ゲームスタート
という流れになっており、この②「神の製作」が曲者でありゲームの広がりを持たせている要素です。
この神は様々な恩恵があり、”神が存在するだけで自国ユニットが強くなる”、”神は頭がいいので研究が捗る”、”毎ターンお金が何故か増える”、”神のくせに戦闘の最前線で無双してる”、という感じで自国にメリットをもたらします。このメリットは神固有の物もあれば、神を製作する際に意図して付与する事も可能です。この恩恵により、自国のユニットの質や戦闘方法等も変わります。これらは自国にとっても・そして敵国家にとっても言えることなので、それらも加味した上で慎重な考察が求められます。なので「対応」ではなく「対策」と言えるでしょう。


[h1]＊は？めっちゃムズくね？＊[/h1]
こうして文字に書き起こすととてもむずかしいゲームに見えますが、実は意外と簡単に遊ぶことが出来ます。私の友人もDominions未経験で一緒に購入しマルチプレイをしましたが、「は？敵国200ユニット倒すのに400ユニットと虎の子騎兵隊で負けたんだが？」と文句を言いながらも手探りで楽しみながら遊んでいます。

こんな感じに、初心者の方でも手探りでそこそこ楽しんで遊べるゲームとなっています。


◆各種評価について
グラフィック　　：★
私は2Dドットグラフィックが大好きなので、私個人の評価としては☆5ですが、昨今のゲームとしては見劣りするため☆1としました。
グラフィックがチープな理由は「内部の演算が複雑すぎるためグラフィックを削る必要がある」という点です。複数のユニット・多すぎる魔法・多すぎる武器/防具等、ゲーム側で考える情報が膨大な為処理を軽くする必要があるのです。この理由を知らない場合「なんで今時こんなグラフィックなんだろう」と思ってしまいますよね。。。


サウンド　　　　：★★★★★
ゲームの雰囲気にマッチしたSE/BGMは素晴らしいの一言につきます。小気味よいクリック音が大好きで、Windowsのクリック音に設定しました。


操作性　　　　　：★★
主な操作は全てマウスクリックで完結できます。しかし、画面上で解説が行われないような便利なショートカットキーが存在する為、そういった点も解説されていればと思い☆2。詳しい操作方法は日本語版Wikiに記載があるのでそちらを参考にすると良いかと思います。


ゲームボリューム：★★★★★
言わずもがな。同じ国家/神で新規ゲームを作成しても同じ展開にはならず、何度も繰り返し遊ぶことが出来ます。また組み合わせも多数あり、「2年以上遊んでいても未だに新規発見があるゲーム」です。


雰囲気　　　　　：★★★★★
ゲームとしての雰囲気は良く、ファンタジーの世界にピッタリなSE/BGMも相成って良い形に仕上がっています。また、足りない部分は脳内補完（私は”転生したらスライムだった件”というラノベが好きでよくそのネタで補間しています）で無問題。


ゲームパフォーマンス：★★
2Dドットは最高の出来なのですが、遠景の3Dグラフィックスの最適化が非常に甘く、ゲームパフォーマンスが低下するレベルで重いです。これらもアップデートで最適化されると思いますが、現時点では☆2。

本人玩mod，单机和亲友直连党。3以前长玩，4只玩过一会，5也玩了一阵子了。如果想入坑，建议只入5代就好。和前面两作相比，5代是一个更为成熟的游戏。开发者在5代做出了很多看起来不起眼但是效果不错的改动，祝福就不多说了，武器系统也很亮眼，Horror入侵的灾厄也非常带感。而且5代对modder的支持也更好，能够实现一些以前无法实现的机制，相信未来会有更丰富的mod提供各种乐趣。

那么dominions5是什么？这是一款名为神域的、扮演一个伪神率领自己的眷族，打败其他伪神及其眷族而成为真神的策略游戏。和其他策略游戏不同，神域的重点在于战争。所有的种田、科技（魔法）、外交、养成都是为战服务的。自动执行的战争只能让你看到战斗回放，想要取得胜利，就只能提前运筹帷幄，在策略考虑（法术研究的顺序，战斗时法术施放的顺序，部队的命令）上绞尽脑汁。可以说战略感十足了。

但以上都不重要，想要在多人对战的神域中登上神座，你最需要的是一副好嘴炮。

In Dominions 5, you play the role of one of many Pretender Gods who are each vying for supremacy through their ruling over a nation of people who worship them after the sudden dissapearance of the Supreme God.

Dominions 5 is a turn-based 4X game where you lead any one of 60+ different nations of people/creatures/beings with a focus on war and area control.

Pros
- Risk on super crack.
- Diverse cast of nations with unique gameplay from evil Greek forest creatures to undead remnants of the Roman Empire to Aztec-like lizard men, we can go on.
- Gigantic magic system allowing for casting battle magic, creating artifacts/gear for your army and casting ritual spells to affect the strategy layer.
- Unique playthroughs due to combination of Pretender God creation, 60+ nations, random map generation.
- Turn-based Total-War-esque battles are a blast to prepare and watch.
- Excellent keyboard shortcuts.

Cons
- Graphics are potato.

If you like 4X games and fantasy worlds with tons of depth and replayability then you might be interested in Dominions 5.

39778325.review: Unique strategy game with tons of replayability, lots of units, customizable God characters, tons of spells and overall just a solid and deep strategy experience. Would have liked if they'd added a diplomacy system this time around but the game is good and worth the money.

39759174.review:
This is the best 4x game I have ever played. And I have played a lot of them.

You know how in Total War games you end up repeatedly reloading the game to re-roll an assassination attempt? Not in this game, because it is a rogue-like 4x game: you can only quit by saving, you can only save by quitting, and there is only one save. You live with your mistakes and losses, and learn to make the best of them, and recover from them. This makes for a much more interesting, challenging and rewarding game than you would get from any other 4x game.

You know how in Total War you get fed up with controlling the battles since it's just the same old tactics: artillery/mages behind archers behind infantry with cavalry to take out the enemy artillery, or intercept enemy cavalry to protect your own artillery if they have cavalry. Rinse and repeat. Well in Dominions you give your orders when you build your army, then just sit back and watch the carnage. No need to the exact same thing every battle. You know how your army is designed to work, so why keep going through the motions? Ever played Gratuitous Space Battles? It's like that, but in a fully fleshed out 4x, with old school complexity (lots of complexity). You know how in Total War there are problems with balancing the auto resolve? If auto is too effective there is no need to fight the battles, if it's too ineffective you have to fight all of them. And they never seem to get it quite right. There is no auto resolve in Dominions. All battles are fully simulated according to the standing orders you gave the troops, and their AI. You just decide if you need to watch them to see if you need to re-calibrate those orders, or try a different army composition. Or to cackle maniacally as your minions head into the meat grinder.

Your avatar in the game is a living god, heavily customisable at the start of the game. You can build your god as a massive monster able to devour whole armies on it's own, pushing for early game wins, or play as a literal fountain of blood, immobile, but vibrating with tremendous power and menace, giving huge bonuses to your empire and laying foul plagues upon cities who fail to bend the knee.

The game is massively moddable, already with a multitude, nay a plethora of mods, with custom factions and much much more:

http://s7.zetaboards.com/Dom3mods/topic/1274067/1/

And yes, the Warhammer mods are slowly but surely trickling in as we speak.
There is no other 4x game like this. This is the 4x game I always wanted to play, the one that existed dormant in the corners of my dreams, yet which reality failed to manifest. No longer, for Dominions 5 is here. And it is glorious.

39741967.review:
Everything new in Dominions 5 is almost identically, exactly what I wished had been changed about Dominions 4. The fortifications have been streamlined into overall upgrades, the bless superabilities are customizable, and combat is in real-time. I love this game and I love what they're doing.

For anyone who hasn't played Dominions 4, this is a turn-based empire game such as Total War: Warhammer, only instead of investing time and money on graphics, it's all put into adding 100s of different species, races, monsters, units, spells etc. into the game. So each unit is litterally two sprites, the normal stand, and the moving sprite. The lack of animation means that they can't do a ton of more things, and honestly it doesn't detract from the strategy, tactics, or coolness of it all.

There are 3 time ages that you can play in, each has like, 20?ish different empires, the early age is more magical, the later age is more conventional warfare, while the middle one is more...middle! There are different ways to win.

Another one of the main differences that this game offers is religion. It affects the strength of your 'god' (did I mention your main leader of your empire is a 'god'?) and if you can snuff out the enemy's religion, their god dies (and their empire dies with it). Religion spreads around the world and you can make it happen faster by using monks / priests / sacrifices / missionaries / inquisitors / etc. (there's really so many units and things in this game).

The races/deities/empires are inspired by many things. Some are themed around the various dozens of mythologies from around the world. Others feel as though they came more or less from conventional high fantasy games. Others yet are also completely unique to this game. There is so much variety it's just oh-so fascinating.

The battles work by moving generals into a territory that has an enemy force inside it. Basic troops are assigned to generals, and the player selects where on the battlefield all the units start (before they move or you ever see the enemy, mind you). You can give the units and generals orders too, but for the most part you can only guess what would be ideal for when a battle occurs. It could be that the enemy had flying units hiding in wait and despite having knights flanking their snake monsters and a line of mercenaries charging forward, their flying units may decide to fly to the back of your forces and take out all your commanders, mages and archers, so it can be a very unpredictable thing. You can only wait until the turn has been processed to know the results of each battle.

Did I mention that everyone's turns are processed simultaneously? So it's perfect for Play-By-E-Mail (PBEM) matches. Of course you can play by network, or hotseat, of course single player's always there, too. So many options!

Anyone who's into role-playing, into fantasy, into strategy/tactics, or who just needs a break from slow triple-A titles should definitely try this out. It will totally be worth it.
